1.content:
Let's get started!


Bless Her Heart—

Carrie Cooleyfinger and her daughter Katie have just moved to a new town. And as much trouble as her daughter is having fitting in on a soccer team that she hates, Carrie is having just as much trouble making friends with the other moms.

Until she comes across the coolest moms of Milton High; Shelby Sullivan, Flo Folly, and Dillon Duncan. They're the most popular ladies on the PTA, and Carrie wants a slice of what they have. Soccer momming, day-drinking, art galleries... it all sounds like so much fun!

But there's a little more than Southern Hospitality at play behind these moms paying for her food, pouring her drinks, and inviting her into their charmed lives. After all, Shelby and her friends need someone to make them look good by comparison...


Caleb, Cat, & Cutie Pie's—

Caleb is a nerdy guy. Even though he's not all that popular with the ladies, he's still friendly and sociable. He goes to the comic book shop every Wednesday and plays his video games—what's not to love?

However, this all changes once he meets Cat, an absolute babe who works at the Cutie Pie's Confectionary just a few doors down from the comic shop! He's smitten with her at first sight, and so is she! It's a match made in heaven!

However, being Cat's boyfriend carries a heavy weight with it. Mostly around Caleb's gut!


Stacy's Mom—

Stacy Stanford, like most of us, has a mother. It was just the two of them for a while, but then she went and got re-married to a guy named Stewart. All pretty normal so far, right?

Well, around the time that Stacy graduates high school, her mother Stella and her step-father Stewart sit her down and warn her that when she sees her mother next, she's going to look a little different...

Because they both have a weight gain fetish, and Stella Stanford-Sterns is going to intentionally gain as much weight as possible. Stacy is, somewhat understandably, perturbed.



Life of Haley—

Haley West tried to live on her own. After high school, she moved away from home and did her level best at being a grown-up. But unfortunately, she couldn't quite crack it.

Coming back to her mom with her tail between her legs, Haley is welcomed back with open arms as Mrs. West shakes off the empty nest syndrome and spoils Haley rotten! She doesn't have to get a job, her back-to-college clothes are paid for, and (most importantly) there's a big meal waiting for her on the table at every opportunity!

Haley is at the center of a cast of characters as she begins to chub up under her mother's roof, with her old friends Courtney, Dani, and Mackenzie to potentially chunk up with her along the ride...

11.content:
Carrie hated soccer.

Even as a child she’d hated it. Her mother had forced her onto the team last-minute, none of the other kids really liked her, and she thought that the uniform was the ugliest shade of puke green. Her team had never won in the four years she’d played, and she’d just never really shaken all of the negative feelings attached to the sport. It always made her think of how much she always hated her mom for making her do stuff “for her own good”. Stuff that she’d “thank her for later”.

And yet, here she was on the bleachers, doing her best to cheer as loud as she could.

Quality parenting, right? As much resentment as she felt towards her mother and this stupid European excuse for football, she’d gone and enrolled her own daughter on the team only to be met with just as much enthusiasm.

Katie hadn’t been taking the move well. Divorce was always hardest on the kids, or so she’d heard, but Carrie couldn’t help but worry about her daughter. Starting a new school had especially rough—the new job meant that she had to move poor Katie to an entirely new school district, and during the middle of middle school no less. She’d more or less spent all of eighth grade in her room, talking on her phone or playing her games. She hadn’t made any friends the previous year, and she’d spent practically all Summer stuck inside being a slug. Sure, her grades had improved, but for how long? It wasn’t healthy to stay cooped up all the time playing Overwatch, and Carrie sure didn’t want her bright, bubbly daughter to find herself ostracized during high school. The last thing Carrie wanted to deal with was a full-on teenaged rebellion, complete with Satan stars and black lipstick, in the middle of her already gripping with a nasty case of becoming suddenly single.

So, without much idea as to what else to do, Carrie decided that Katie was going to play Soccer.

It was for her own good.

(ugh)

God, she hated this.

As alone as Katie must have felt down there, she felt even more alone up in the stands. She knew nobody. It was so much easier when Katie went to the same school district she had growing up. All the moms and dads were just people she went to high school with. She didn’t even have a husband to barnacle herself to anymore—she might have even taken him over the crowd of strangers, if just for the length of these stupid soccer matches.

At least, she thought to herself, that from the stands she could enjoy a good chili dog.

And maybe, in another life, that would have been the highlight of her daughter’s soccer matches. The sewer pipe that was her life might have a little crack that led to the sunshine that was “wow my daughter might hate this as much as I do, but boy how about them chili dogs?” and life would have just been grand.

Instead, right after the kickoff of the second quarter, that was when she saw them.

How could she not have seen them before? The three of them had been talking throughout the entire game; laughing, taking pictures, having such a good time. They were all dressed in the same golden number 9 jersey—SULLIVAN written across all their backs in solidarity. They seemed so… together. Like they knew what they were doing with their lives. Even with the whistle blowing down on the field and the stands clamoring around them, Carrie’s attention was drawn intrinsically towards the conversation that she couldn’t really hear but so desperately wanted to be a part of. The three of them just seemed so… so cool.

And somehow, in some way, Carrie knew that that was what she needed in her shambled life. A group of friends, just like that. Ones who would come to soccer matches and make it fun for her. Friends that she could talk to and who could show her around the town. Friends who she could bitch about her cheating ex-husband to.

She’d spent so much time worrying about Katie being moved clear across the state, having no friends and nothing to do, that she’d totally missed that she was in the exact same situation as her daughter.

It was so obvious; how could she have not seen it before?

“H-Hi!” Carrie said with a small wave as the name on the back of their jerseys evaporated from her mind, “Are you, uh… players’ moms? Moms of players?”

“Guilty as charged.” The redheaded one in the middle said with a little laugh and a dismissive wave, her pretty voice lilting in the Autumn heat, “I’m Summer’s mom—you know, the co-captain? Its only her second year and she’s already pretty much in charge.”

“Oh wow.” Carrie was practically starstruck by these women, fuck the kid, “So, are you all…?”

“Oh no, we’re just here to watch the game—we go to Shelby’s girl’s games, she comes to our girls’ things.” The blonde on the end furthest to Carrie laughed, “’Are we all’! Us, all together like that, can you imagine?”

The three of them tittered at the insinuation, Carrie laughing along dumbly and for a little too long. The other mothers stared at her for the briefest of moments before carrying on.

“Are your girls on the team, darlin’?” the tall brunette asked with a piqued eyebrow

“Girls? No, just girl. One girl. Number, uh…” crap crap crap what was her daughter’s number? “Katie. Her name’s Katie.”

“Ohhhh so you’re…” the same one winced slightly, “Katie’s mom… riiiight.”

“Number 5!” Carrie blurted out, “Katie’s number 5.”

And, all at once, the other mothers peered down into the soccer field for what had to have been the first time since the game started. They scrutinized each of the golden little specks before one of them—the one furthest from Carrie—pointed her out.

“Ohhh!” the one in the middle said, “She’s… well, she’s definitely… a player!”

“A little… slow, huh?”

“She’s… a kind of big for her age, isn’t she?”

Carrie’s blood ran cold. What was the protocol here? It wasn’t like she really cared how good her daughter was at soccer. It wasn’t like Katie even cared about how good she was at soccer. Was this something to get offended about? If she got offended, did that mean she couldn’t hang out with these cool moms who totally had their lives together? This was the kind of thing that someone really needed to explain to newly single parents…

“Yeah, she’s still learning.” Carrie laughed it off, “Not really into Soccer yet… but she will be!”

“Well, my name’s Shelby.” The redheaded one continued in an almost bored sort of voice, “Shelby Sullivan.”

“Florence Folly.” The blonde one smiled piteously, “Call me Flo.”

“Dillon Duncan, charmed.” The taller brunette said in a curt sort of voice

“Uh, C-Carrie.” the only woman not in a jersey said with a smile, “It’s nice to meet you.”

“Nice to meet you too, hun.” Shelby broached dismissively, “Well we’re here at every soccer game—

“Or Football game.” Dillon interjected, “Go Cougars!”

“Art Club events too.” Flo wriggled her fingers, “It was so nice to meet you, sweetie!”

“Don’t be afraid to stop by and say hi.”

And just like that, the three of them turned inward, back unto themselves. Carrie stood there for just a few seconds, trying to think of some clever sign off, before eventually just doing that awkward bleacher shuffle back to her seat. It wasn’t until she was seated that she realized she’d been talking with all those other women with a giant chili stain on her flannel shirt.

“That went well.”

Carrie groaned, sinking her head deep into her hands. Moments like this called for another chili dog.

111.content:
Carrie had been waiting in the car when Katie tumbled into the backseat. Sweating like a mule, she threw her gym bag at the driver side rear door from the inside and slowly wriggled her way into the back seat of their trusty sedan.

“You don’t want to sit up front?” her mother asked, looking into the back seat

“No. Wanna lay down.” The poor girl panted, brown hair matted to her forehead as she flattened herself across the back seats, “Just for a little bit.”

“You know if I hit the brakes hard, you’ll go rolling off, right?”

“Then don’t brake so hard.”

Katie and Carrie had many things in common. She was hardly her father’s child at all—Carrie and her daughter had the same dark brown hair, the same big green eyes and fair skin. She was awfully freckled, though, that much she did get from her ex-husband. More recently his heritage was beginning to become more apparent as puberty set in. Katie was already developing a chest that had to come from somewhere other than her side of the family tree. It seemed like they went shopping for bras every other month. But more importantly, and a little worryingly, Katie had started to put on weight.

It was completely normal and understandable—Carrie’s seat sat a little wider herself now that she had found herself newly and suddenly single—and no one blamed her daughter for it. Her parents splitting up must have been difficult to deal with, and her way of doing so had been moving from Silver to Platinum as a D.Va main. Compounded with her changing body and Carrie’s admittedly lackluster grocery shopping habits, it was only natural that her daughter was starting to put away a little chub.

That had been the initial reasoning behind her joining the soccer team. A physical activity and a goal-oriented mentality would not only keep her from falling too hard into rebellion, but it would also keep her in shape. Carrie figured that it would have been a win-win, if it felt like anybody won. She didn’t like going to these games, and Katie definitely didn’t like playing in them.

But even still, moments like this called for encouragement—one of those Mom Answers.

“It’ll get easier.” Carrie offered a smile from the front seat, cranking the ignition, “You know, keep going to practice, a few more games…”

The utter distaste that Katie had for the prospect of more games looming ominously in her future was made evident by the widening of her eyes. Her formerly flush face seemed to whiten a bit as the words ‘a few more games’ hit her like a ton of bricks. It made Carrie feel like crap.

“It’ll get easier.”

“I want McDonalds.” Katie grunted, working her way into a seated position before her mother backed out of the parking space, “If you’re not gonna let me quit and give me Mom Answers, I deserve McDonalds.”

“Fair enough.” Carrie laughed as she put the car into reverse, “I think you’ve earned some fast food.”

“I deserve all the fast food.” Katie grumbled, whipping out her phone, “So you met Summer’s mom?”

Carrie winced as she recalled her painful first encounter with the other moms. God, it had been so painful. She’d spent the rest of the game alternating between looking longingly at them and trying desperately not to make eye contact. She must have come across like a total mental patient.

“Yeeees?” Carrie’s smile turned into a grimace, “I, uh… was she the uh…”

“Really cool mom with two other really cool friends?”

“Um… yeah, I… may have met her. In the stands. For a minute.” Was that a proper way of saying that she’d totally embarrassed herself, “Why do you ask?”

“Because Summer just texted me about it.” Katie pointed to her phone, “She said you had chili on your shirt.”

“It does not say that!”

“Yeah, it does.” Katie flipped the phone around to show her mother, who felt about an inch tall right about now, “Says you didn’t even remember my number. Wow, thanks Mom.”

“Oh jeez…” Carrie grimaced, finding it particularly hard to focus on getting out of this stupid over-packed parking lot while her daughter read her her rights, “Does it say anything else about me? Maybe something that doesn’t make me look like the world’s shittiest, slobbiest mother?”

“I mean Mrs. Sullivan is throwing a party for the team at her house, and she wanted to know if we could come.”

“We?” Carrie’s face lit up, butterflies in her stomach as she pressed that precious little w-word, “Like, if you and me could come?”

“Yeah, but like…” Katie’s eyes got wide again as the prospect of further socialization truly dawned on her, “You don’t really… want to go to—”

“Katie, honey, it’s important to make friends with your teammates!” Carrie’s smile was a mile wide as she pulled out onto the main road outside of the school, “It’d be a shame if we didn’t go support the Cougars—”

“But Mom!”

“—It’s for your own good, Katie. Doing things you don’t like builds character!” Carrie said in her best Mom voice, “And besides, we’re in a new town, with people we don’t know… it might be fun to make some friends that don’t require a very expensive internet bill! Support the team, put in some face time with Summer and the captain, maybe…”

“Fine.” Katie harrumphed, “But this is going in the book I’m writing when I grow up.”

“And people will buy it because you’ll have friends to advertise to.”

“Mom.”

1111.content:
For the better part of a week, Carrie had been both looking forward to and dreading this party.

On the one hand, it was a social event. And for all of the fun she tried to be and as much of the negativity from her old life as she tried to leave behind her, it was pretty hard to be much fun at these kinds of things when you were a recently divorced single mother of a teenaged girl in a new city where you knew absolutely no one. What was she going to talk about? If someone was stupid enough to ask her to “tell (me) about yourself!” Carrie wouldn’t just break the ice, she’d melt the whole damn glacier with how awkward it was.

But on the other hand, it was another chance at talking to them again; the coolest moms that Carrie had ever met. Shelby Sullivan, Dillon Duncan and Flo—not Florence—Folly.

There was just something about them that Carrie felt like she needed in her life. They were magnetic and trendy—three close friends with three daughters who were all involved with the school and did things like throw parties for the soccer team, all while looking incredible and seeming so confident. Carrie had been taken with them since the first time she’d laid eyes on them.

Unfortunately, that time hadn’t ended up so well. But this time, hopefully, would go better.

The Sullivans lived in an old plantation-style house—the kind that Carrie would look at longingly in the ads knowing that she could have never afforded it even when she and her ex-husband were still together. The house had been painted a pastel, but not obnoxious, pink color that really made the white trim pop against the autumn-brown shutters. It was a little off the beaten path, but that had only made it that much more rewarding when she’d found it—the house seemed so much bigger when there were so few neighbors around. All the telltale signs of a southern party were there—balloons on the mailbox, plenty of cars in the driveway, and teenagers in bathing suits chatting by the above-ground pool off the deck.

“Oh wow.” Carrie actually said aloud, aghast, as she purposefully parked so as not to block anyone in, “This is… nice.”

“Yeah, Summer’s family’s rich.” Katie said in a nonplussed sort of way, reaching around to get her bag, “Her dad does something, I don’t know.”

The two of them stepped out of their 2001 Honda Accord—careful not to hit the BMW parked next to them—and followed the paved walkway up to the front porch. Katie had hardly made it up the steps when her mother had excitedly rang the doorbell.

“Oh, it’s Kitty!”

Flo had come to the door, wine glass in hand—she was the one whose daughter was in Art Club. Carrie had done some superb Facebook stalking on these ladies, not only in preparation for the party, but out of just a sheer fascination with them. The more she knew ahead of time about them, the less likely she was to get caught off-guard and say something stupid.

“Uh, it’s Ka—”

“Yup, we’re here!” Carrie took a step inside, her daughter trudging behind, “Here to, uh… here to party!”

“Wonderful—Kitty, sweetheart, the girls are all out in the back if you want to put on your swimsuit.” The blonde uncurled two fingers from the bulb and pointed deeper into the house, “Carrie, sweetie, some of the moms are upstairs, do you want to say hi?”

“Yes.”

Carrie couldn’t have started up the stairs sooner, leaving her daughter to discover where “the back” was all by herself. The butterflies in her stomach were practically rabid now, tying knots in her small intestine. She hadn’t eaten anything in anticipation of the party—didn’t want to be to full just in case their host offered them something to eat. As the anxiety mixed with the hunger, she was beginning to regret that decision. It would have been even more embarrassing for her stomach to growl in the middle of this all-too-important second chance with the Cool Moms…

“Right through here.” Flo opened the door, “Hey girls, Kitty’s mom wanted to pop by and say hello!”

The two other women had been in a sitting room—a sort of needless room that just served space for a place to gossip. Three couches, a fireplace, and some kitschy Southern decoration. A Live, Laugh, Love vinyl was stuck to the east wall, while Eat, Drink, & be Merry was on the wall behind them. The furniture was all antique, and the fragrance (not to mention the wall decals) made it look more like a dentist’s waiting room than a place that someone actually lived. But the magnificence of its occupants more than made up for the more generic decoration.

Shelby—the redheaded mom of the soccer team’s co-captain—had been lounging on the loveseat directly within Carrie’s line of sight. When Carrie came through the door, she lazily extended her wine arm in a half-hearted toast. Her long red hair was down, rolling over her shoulders in perfectly done amber waves. She had on a gray flowy top that left her shoulders exposed and tight high-waisted jeans; her flats had been kicked off next to the loveseat.

Dillon—the taller brunette and the mother of head cheerleader D.W. Duncan—had been sitting on the seat across from Shelby, dressed in a flowery sundress. Her tanned arm had been thrown over the back of the lounge with one of her long legs kicked comfortably over the other. She looked back towards the door with a smile, took a sip, and then turned back towards her hostess. Apparently, they had come back in the middle of a conversation.

“Hey darlin’—it’s good to see you again.” Dillon said with raised eyebrows as she took another sip

“Definitely, always great seeing you.” Shelby whispered a mean little laugh into her glass

“Always, uh… great to be seen!” Carrie said brightly, “Katie’s, uh, really been looking forward to this party.”

“Well, Kitty and my Summer are friends, of course she can come over any time.”

Friends! Her daughter had friends! Her daughter and Shelby Sullivan’s daughter were friends! Her daughter was friends with this cool girl! Who had a cool mom! Who had a friend group of cool moms that she could insert herself into, and therefore have friends herself—Cool friends!

“Well, we’re planning on wrapping things up around seven.” Shelby said, carefully peeling herself back to a sitting position, then a stand, as she walked slowly over to the fashionable end table that served no other purpose than holding the small collection of alcohol that they’d brought out for the event, “It’s okay if you get here a little late, but call ahead if it’s going to be like nine or something.”

“Oh!” Carrie’s tone dropped a bit, “I thought, uh… I thought I’d just hang out with you guys.”

She was met with blank stares.

“You know, moms hanging out with other moms, doing the whole…” Carrie gulped, “Day drinking thing, apparently.”

Flo, Shelby, and Dillon all glanced at one another. The pit of Carrie’s stomach fell out from the bottom, letting all the butterflies out. There was a minute of palpable silence between the four of them.

“Why not?” Dillon finally said with a raise of her glass and earning the quiet ire of her hostess “The pizza should be here in a minute anyway—stay for lunch!”

“Of course you can hang out with us for just a little while, hun.” Shelby purred, handing Carrie her refilled wine glass, “Dillon, honey, would you mind going downstairs and bringing up the vodka? And try not to trip and fall down the stairs on your way back up. You might hurt yourself.”

Carrie couldn’t help but feel a little invasive. She didn’t want to put them off, and she didn’t want to seem needy. But at the same time, Eee it was happening! She was going to get to sit and do Mom stuff for the first time in what felt like forever. She was going to have friends and drink and bitch about their daughters and other moms!

“You come sit next to me, sweetie.” Flo said with a pat of Carrie’s shoulder, leading her towards the unoccupied loveseat directly across the fireplace, “I’ll be right back with the hard stuff.”

11111.content:
Coming to this party having not eaten anything was a mistake.

She’d skipped lunch in hopes of being seen as a good guest. Just in case someone offered her food, Carrie wouldn’t have wanted to turn it down. What Shelby, Flo, and Dillon had offered her instead was copious amounts of alcohol. And pizza, eventually, but that hadn’t come until about forty-five minutes and a glass and a half of merlot had passed. Carrie was already tipsy by the time one of the girls had brought up two boxes of pizza—Cheese and Pepperoni—for the already toasty moms.

“I wish I wasn’t afraid to eat just anything.” Shelby said wistfully as she took a dainty bite of her slice of cheese pizza, “Carrie, you’re living the dream.”

“I am?” Carrie managed to say through her third slice of pepperoni, “Why’s that?”

“You just seem so… comfortable!” Flo added helpfully, tipping her wine glass back and downing another swallow, “I mean that’s, what, your third slice of pizza?”

Carrie’s stomach reknotted at the thought of these women judging her for eating so much. She almost wished that she could go back and take back having picked up that third slice, right then and there. She’d just been so hungry, and she needed some carbs to soak up all this wine!

“R-Right…” Carrie stammered, her face flush with red wine and embarrassment, “I, um… I skipped breakfast this morning…”

“Oh no, hun, don’t apologize.” Shelby said with a bit of a slur after she’d swallowed, “One of the upsides of not having a husband is that there’s nobody around to tell you you’ve been getting fat.”

Carrie felt her guts pour out onto the sofa. Was Shelby calling her fat? Sure, she wasn’t exactly the skinniest mom on the bleachers at their daughters’ soccer matches, but she wasn’t fat by any means! The wine in her blood boiled as a heat began to rise behind her eyes at the insult—something that everyone else seemed to notice. Sensing a potential commotion, and perhaps having dealt with such an issue in the past, both Dillon and Flo seemed to quietly swoop into recovery mode at their hostess’s faux pas.

“Is Troy still pickin’ on you about that, honey?” Dillon drawled from the other sofa, having kicked her shoes off to stretch over the armrests, “You tell him right where to shove that kind of talk.”

While Shelby and Dillon discussed their opinions of Mr. Sullivan’s couth, Flo leaned over and quietly (as quietly as a buzzed Mom could) informed Carrie of the source of Shelby’s sourness.

“That wasn’t about you, honey, honest.” The shorter woman purred with pizza and merlot on her breath, “Shelby’s just a little upset about some comfort weight she’s gone and put on.”

“It’s not comfort weight if I’m not comfortable with it!” Shelby griped from her sofa having overheard Flo’s low talking as she poured herself another shot of vodka, “M’damn husband keeps buggin’ me about hittin’ the gym ‘cause a fifteen—no, ten lousy pounds!”

“Oh my God your accent.” Dillon giggled, “If Troy wants to pick on you about anything getting thicker, you should just get drunk around him.”

Carrie reclined back into her spot on the couch as her temper cooled and a wave of relief washed over her, taking another bite of pizza and a gulp of wine with her. Her anger slowly melted at the small display that Shelby was giving, her face as red as her hair as she drawled on thickly about her husband with Dillon and Flo.

But now that she was looking at her, Carrie did notice that Shelby was a little thicker than the other moms. Dillon was stick-thin and long, but even Flo, who was about half a foot shorter than Carrie, was a bit trimmer around the waist than the redheaded soccer mom. She still probably weighed a little less than Carrie, not that Carrie was a cow or anything, but she could understand how a couple of extra pounds could rile a girl up like that. Having to throw out her jeans on top of her husband hadn’t exactly been the most pleasant experience.

“You’re not that big, you know.” Carrie offered helpfully, “I mean, you’re about my size, right?”

“Not that big. Pssh.” Shelby slammed another shot, “Honey, to my husband, any woman over one thirty is a cow.”

“Moo.”

“Oh Dillon hush, you’re a giant.” Shelby grumbled, “Have some more pizza, Carrie honey.”

Carrie was a little too drunk to say no to more pizza. Even if all this commotion had started over extra slices, Carrie had been enjoying herself. The other moms seemed to like her a little more, even if it was just the alcohol talking. Besides—Shelby said it herself, she was living the dream. What’s more, she hadn’t once mentioned her cheating ex-husband or made things awkward. Even if these women kept getting her daughter’s name wrong, and even if they were a little catty, Carrie felt like she’d made some real progress here—why not celebrate with a few extra slices?

“Don’t mind if I do.” Carrie grunted a little leaning forward, taking her fourth slice from the box, “I mean, since I’m living the dream and all.”

Admittedly, four was pushing it a little. Her usual limit was three—and that was only once in a while. Three pieces of pizza had left her stomach feeling full, pressing tight against her jeans. If she’d been at home, she would have simply unbuttoned them, but not here. Not in front of these ladies who she had just gotten to like her. The last thing she wanted to do was be known as “the fat friend”

But a fourth slice wouldn’t kill anyone.

Neither would a fifth.

“Oh jeez…” Carrie burped into the back of her hand, “I ate too much.”

Half of a box of pizza had gone into Carrie before she realized just what she had done. The wine had left her head foggy and her inhibitions hazy. It wasn’t until she was choking down the crust of her sixth piece, her belly rounded out beneath her shirt, that she started to feel sick. All the wine, all that pizza, all the grease…

“We all ate a little too much.” Flo, who had stopped at two pieces, said with a dismissive swat of the hand, “Don’t feel too bad—you said you skipped breakfast, right?”

“A rookie mistake.” Dillon—a little more toasted than anyone else—said with a little snort

“I did.” Carrie nodded sleepily, “Hey Shelby—next time you want to show your husband a cow, tell him about your friend who managed to pack away six pieces of pizza, huh?”

Shelby—who had dried up a bit after having put back four slices of pizza—shifted her gaze to the stuffed brunette sitting across from her. Next to Flo, leaned back in the couch, and helplessly tipsy and full. Eat Drink & be Merry scrawled over her head in black vinyl cursive on the wall as she cradled her food baby.

The woman had eaten six pieces of pizza. Compared to her four, well that was just a plain lot.

“I’ll do that, hun.” Shelby purred, fumbling with the bottle of mineral water she’d kept nearby, “I’ll make sure to tell him all about you…”

111111.content:
It would take more time, but Carrie had made a decent first step in butting in that fateful day of the Pool Party.

She and the other mothers had exchanged numbers after everyone had sobered up. The three of them had even added her on Facebook—Carrie was now privy to all of the memes they stole, the posts they shared, and she could get more than just a glimpse of what appeared to be their idyllic lives through their daughters’ various headshots, exterior shots of their home, and perfectly choreographed “happy mistakes” in the kitchen that always seemed to work out in their favor. Carrie was getting closer and closer to everything that she wanted, and this was a great first step.

More promisingly on their part, they invited her to just about every school event—and boy did these women spend a lot of time together. Between the three of them, they seemed to have all the free time in the world. Shelby didn’t work, freeing up her schedule to post memes from WifeMom&WineLife on Facebook, while Flo worked part-time at an Art Gallery and Dillon made her own hours at a screen-printing shop. Carrie couldn’t go to everything that they wanted her to go to, but she made sure to catch everything that happened after five ‘o’ clock where she could. Whether it was because they were taking pity on her because they knew she didn’t know the town very well, or if it was because they genuinely liked her, Carrie couldn’t tell. And honestly, she couldn’t care less—she just wished that she had more time to really integrate herself with her new friends.

If it wasn’t soccer games, cheer meets, or art club showings, most of their time was spent at Shelby’s impressive plantation house. It was on one of these nights, when Shelby had invited Carrie and Katie over for dinner, that they got to meet Mr. Sullivan.

“You must be Kitty’s mom.”

Admittedly, Carrie had not gone into the meeting with high expectations. Her first impression of the man was a wine-stained recollection that he had some kind of problem with Shelby’s weight. Having had more than her fair share of husband problems, she walked into the front door with an unconsciously less-than-enthusiastic point of view. The fact that her sweater didn’t quite fit as loose as it used to, and her jeans were a little tight only made her that much more conscious of his issue with women keeping their waists trim.

He was a tall man with red hair, like his daughter and his wife, and he was a bit paunchy. His belly bunched against the white button-up tucked into his jeans, and he could have used a shave. But despite Carrie’s lingering opinions of him as a chauvinist, she was a little taken. She could certainly see how he managed to attract a woman like Shelby Sullivan, that much was for sure.

“Katie’s mom, yes.”

“Go ahead and head on inside—Summer’s getting the table all set.”

The two of them had gone inside, said hello to their respective counterparts, and took their seats at the table. An already uncorked bottle of red wine was there, with Shelby waiting for her friend glass in hand, as the two of them became said their hellos.

And honestly, it was really nice—something that Carrie had never thought she’d have again. Seeing her daughter make friends with an older girl (Summer was such a nice girl!) and having wine over dinner… just that sort of normalcy that she hadn’t realized she was missing since the divorce.

However, while Carrie was preoccupied getting to know her daughter’s new friend, Shelby had excused herself deeper into the kitchen to begin serving dinner. She’d finished her glass of wine, set it aside, and put both hands on the mashed potatoes she’d slaved over making the “right” way. No butter, no salt, no cheese. Boring as all get out—but that was just one of the ways she could keep Troy off nagging about her weight.

“Your friend’s nice.” Troy said as an aside, finishing his bottle of beer and tossing it into the trashcan by the door, “Real handsome woman, too.”

“Mm.” Shelby pursed her lips as she lifted the boring potatoes, her expression as flat and loveless as their sex life, “Eats like a cow though.”

“Well she puts it in the right places, at least.” Troy said loosely with a little chuckle, “Wouldn’t kick her out of bed for eating biscuits.”

1111111.content:
Despite the placidity of her tone, Shelby felt a lump growing in her gut. She’d never taken it kindly when Troy complimented other women, like Dillon or Flo. Him getting drunk, leaning over (or coming home drunk, barging in at random) and brazenly mentioning that he wasn’t asking for a threesome, but if he were asking for a threesome, it’d be with her and her “pretty friends” had become less of a source of stress and more of a party favor. It still hurt, but she’d become numb enough to it to find some humor in it. But for him to compliment Carrie, her recently-divorced, working-class friend who ate six slices of pizza the other day after a whole bottle of wine—Carrie, who was the same size as her, over how pretty she was…

Well that stung a little bit.

“Well, keep it up hun, I’ll be sure to tell her you think so.”

Shelby said coolly and calmly as she handed him the potatoes, the ones he’d asked her to make as bland and as boring as possible ‘for her own good’ and smiled venomously into his beard.

“You two can bond over what it’s like to be divorced.”

***


Carrie had no idea that her friend was so unhappy in her marriage. You would have never known that the two of them detested each other so much with the way that Mr. and Mrs. Sullivan carried themselves at the dinner table! They were always pleasant and courteous, even to one another, in the face of company. And with two new faces—not like Flo and Dillon, who were well aware of their marital turmoil—they had all the reason to be on their best behavior and play the parts of perfect hosts.

They accomplished the act by directing any and all focus on two things—their daughter, and wine. But Shelby hadn’t been blind to the looks that her husband had been giving her friend. Lucky for her, Carrie had been far too focused on keeping the conversation about her friend and her daughter. But Shelby was glad that her husband was watching—she knew exactly what would happen if she kept filling Carrie up with wine.

“Summer’s doing a great job.” Shelby said, a bottle tipping over the brim of Carrie’s glass, “More wine, hun?”

“Oh, I couldn’t…” Carrie said, swimmy headed as she tucked back into her plate, “I’ve got to drive home.”

“So, you’ll stay a little later!” Shelby said dismissively, plopping another helping of potatoes onto her friend’s plate, “Here, these will help soak that right up.”

“I couldn’t.” Carrie said again in a shallow breath, “I’m so full.”

“You don’t like it?” Shelby gasped, “It’s my mother’s recipe—minus the butter, cheese, and, well, anything fun.”

The redheaded hostess tucked into a frown and grabbed at the sides of the dish

“Well, I suppose I could always thro—”

“No!”

Carrie leaned forward a bit too much, too fast. She felt nauseous with all the food weighing on her stomach, and the wine sloshing in her belly. The last thing she wanted to do was to disappoint her new friend, especially when she had gone to all this trouble, and her family had been so kind as to invite the two of them over. And when she was making genuine progress in working her way into their inner circle.

“I mean, um…” Carrie said in the awkward silence that followed her outburst, “I-I’d love some more! Please!”

Shelby smiled wickedly as she filled her plate with the potatoes—as well as the green beans and even an extra piece of cornbread.

Shelby knew Carrie’s type—she’d been dealing with them since high school, when she’d lead the cheer team. Desperate, needy, looking to get with the “cool” friends—it was so sad. She’d decided that it couldn’t hurt to have her around for just a little while, just to spice things up a bit. But she couldn’t have her husband looking at her up and down like she was anything other than the recently divorced, working-class mother that she was.

And the quickest way to do that was to take advantage of Carrie’s enthusiasm and show Troy what she meant when she said that Carrie “ate like a cow.”

Over the course of the dinner, Shelby had practically poured two bottles of wine down Carrie’s throat. The two of them and Troy had stayed at the dinner table while Summer and Katie had gone upstairs—Shelby making sure to give her husband a good look at the woman he’d made the mistake of calling “handsome”.

Poor Carrie was stuffed, her belly rounding out underneath her sweater. She tried to say no, but every time she got out the first syllable, Shelby looked so upset! And in her drunken haze, growing thicker and thicker as the night went on, it made more and more sense to just keep eating.

After all, she’d hate to be a bad guest to her new friend!

“Oh… oh God…” Carrie groaned as she unrolled her sweater, “Shelby, I… I really hate to be rude… but I think I’m gonna pop…”

She was like a beached whale, rolled up to the kitchen table. You could see the curve of her stomach as it pressed against her top, her legs spread in an unconscious attempt at giving her gut a little breathing room. She pushed herself against the wall, away from the table, and as far away from food as she could get. Her drunken, swimmy-headed pants filled the dining room as all conversation had come to a halt—Shelby and Troy having nothing to say to one another except for the former’s cock-browed sneer and the latter’s revulsion at his hoggish dinner guest.

“Oh hun, I know.” Shelby said sweetly, “We all made little piggies of ourselves tonight!”

Forgetting herself, desperate for release, Carrie fumbled with the button on her jeans in a way which she thought was deft and dubious. It was not. Shelby’s smile widened and Troy’s disgust deepened at the sight of her belly sinking that much lower, and the look of utter contentment on her face as she finally felt the pressure lighten.

“Some of us a little more than others.” Shelby winked, “You okay to drive home?”

“I’ll let Katie drive.” Carrie slurred, “Her mama’s waaaay to toasty to get us home…”

The piglet tried to rock herself to a standing position, grunting as she battled her fullness and her lack of balance. The poor thing had stuffed herself so full of food in hopes of not offending her new friend, and she’d gone and drank so much that she hadn’t realized that she’d really overdone it until it was far too late. She may as well have been pinned to that old country dinner table now.

“Want me to go upstairs and get her?” Shelby purred

Carrie could only nod and whimper in response.

***


“What did I tell you?” Shelby said in a satisfied sort of way, “Total cow.”

“I see what y’mean.” Troy said as he kicked off the covers, “That woman can eat.”

The two of them had adjourned themselves to their bedroom late that night. By the time they’d practically rolled that woman out of their kitchen and into her car and their daughters had said goodbye, it was about ten ‘o’ clock. Shelby had made sure that her husband had had plenty of opportunity to see the woman that he’d thought was so pretty and so handsome stuff herself like a Thanksgiving turkey—plenty of time to see his mistake.

She’d barely even minded giving him a post-dinner party old-fashioned. Call it a reward, with the extra bottle of beer he’d had after the goodbyes, for not saying anything mean-spirited about his wife. He’d even given her a little peck on the cheek.

“Almost makes me look kinda skinny, huh?” the redhead added sardonically from over the shoulder, a pointedly heated glare at the back of her husband’s head

“She keeps that up, she’s gonna make every woman look skinny.” Her husband non-answered, staring at his phone, “She looks good now, but if she keeps on eatin’… I don’t know.”

Shelby paused, the sobering mind slowly whirring behind her bright green eyes.

“I mean, not to be mean or anything but…” she asked finally, idea-lets falling into place as she slowly wriggled her way underneath the covers, “You think that she’s gonna get fat?”

“Well yeah, hun, pretty damn big I’d say if tonight was anything to go by.” Troy said in a post-ejaculate exasperation, “Next thing you know we’re gonna have to roll that cow in through the front door every time you and your friends wanna get drunk.”

Once the night fell into place—once Shelby started keeping Carrie stuffed—Troy hadn’t said a thing to her about her portions. She’d managed to sneak in two extra biscuits and another plop of potatoes without her husband noticing. He’d been so focused on how much their guest for the evening had been eating, he hadn’t said anything mean or derogatory about her all night. Even during the hand job.

Maybe this Carrie woman would serve a purpose after all.

“You know, I think you’re right.” Shelby purred, clicking off the lamp on her bedside table, “But with the divorce, being a single mother and all… she needs all the help she can get.”

“Your fat friend needs to find her a man that’ll keep her in shape.” Troy grunted, already nodding off, “Like you got.”

“Mm, of course dear.” Shelby smiled venomously to herself, “But at least my fat friend makes me look good.”

“Amen to that.”

11111111.content:
After that night, Carrie was sure that she had undone all the progress she’d made with her cool new friends. Getting drunk and stuffing herself like a pig in front of Shelby and her husband had been mortifying—even if she had just been trying to be a good guest.

To her surprise, it only seemed to encourage nights over!

Most of the invitations that had come beforehand were during working hours. No matter how much she wanted to attach herself to her new friends, she couldn’t exactly call out every time she received a Facebook invitation about something or other going on around town or at the school. What would she tell her boss? That three really cool, really together, really interesting women wanted her to go check out the new Spice Trade store that opened downtown? She would have been fired the first time she tried that mess!

But after her first dinner over with the Sullivans, Carrie was so surprised—touched, honestly—that her friends started to frequent more events that all of them could go to.

“We’re so sorry we didn’t make you feel welcome darlin’!” Dillon poured Carrie’s Lush Lagoon neatly into her glass as the cicadas chirped off Dillon’s deck, “We all got to talking and figured that it’d be a real shame if we didn’t start hanging out when we could all make it. Don’t you think so?”

“That is so thoughtful.” Carrie said, lightheaded, “And so, so sweet.”

“But not as sweet as this tea.” Flo poured her friend a non-alcoholic glass, “Here honey, have another biscuit while we wait on dinner.”

“You guys are the best.” Carrie bit heartily into another piece of flaky, buttery bread, “Mmm and you’re all such good cooks. I’m so jealous. Poor Katie lives on cereal.”

As time went on and their friendship deepened, Carrie suddenly found herself with most evenings booked. Where she would have normally spent her time after work at home, curled up on the couch and watching Netflix or talking to Katie (usually about Overwatch or how much she hated soccer), now the formerly unoccupied single mother’s nights were filled with fruity cocktails, gossiping in sitting rooms, around kitchen tables, or in rocking chairs on porches, and all of the southern cooking that these women could offer.

Except on Fridays—Fridays were pizza nights.

Spending two out of five, then three out of five, to three out of five and one of the days of the weekend with her friends so quickly and so suddenly had come as a shock to the somewhat reclusive Carrie. Her divorce and loss of a social circle had almost made her forget how much fun she could have with other moms—especially moms that were so rich and had all the stories that came with a rich, lavish lifestyle to tell. They were so welcoming and really made her feel like part of a group.

She hardly noticed that she’d started to put on a little weight—at least, not until it was too late. Looking at herself in the mirror now, she realized why her friends had insisted on going clothes shopping. She was huge!

“You know what you should do, Mom?” Katie commented from her mother’s bed, kicking a soccer ball up in the air just shy of the ceiling, “You know what you should do if you think you’re too fat?”

“Katie, I swear to God.”

“You should join the Soccer Team, mom.” Katie barbed with equal parts good humor and ventilation of her genuine frustration, “It’ll be for your own good.”

“Oh my God.”

“You’ll make new friends, Mom.” Her daughter raspberried, “You can’t stay inside all day playing Overwatch.”

And her daughter was having a little fun at her expense, Carrie knew that. But in all honesty, a little exercise (or a lot of exercise) would have done the poor woman a lot of good. She looked like a blimp—thirty pounds in three months. How does that even happen?

Her waist had taken the brunt of the damage. She’d gone from a little soft to downright chunky in such a short amount of time her wardrobe couldn’t keep up. She muffin-topped over any pairs of jeans that fit (right side of her room) and her belly bulged right past the zippers of the ones that didn’t, if she could work them up her legs (left side). In one case, she’d actually ripped a pair just trying to wrestle them up her flabby thighs. How embarrassing was that?

It was her own fault; eating so much. She’d gotten swept up in having friends, in all the drinking and the gossiping, that she’d hardly noticed the eating. Much less what it had done to her body.

Turning to the side, Carrie winced in revulsion as her belly did the thing. It drooped, like a pouch. Her tits sagged a little lower, hung a little heavier, and sloped slightly to either side of her high belly. She just seemed to jiggle almost everywhere. Her thighs, her arms, her ass. God, she was big. And it was getting to be expensive—all these new clothes weren’t exactly in her single-parent budget.

“Looks like we’re going to Goodwill.” Carrie sighed, “Or maybe the Salvation Army that just opened off Number 9.”

“Ooh, Goodwill.” Katie wiggled her fingers spookily, “I won’t tell your friends.”

“Alright, alright, too far.” Carrie corrected her daughter with a sharp, sudden point. One that rippled in her saggy belly, “You might be able to outrun me, but I’ll still kick your little butt.”

Catching the hint of what almost looked like a double chin in the mirror was enough for Carrie to skip the takeout that came customary with her and her daughter’s trips to Goodwill.

The next time that she hung out with her friends, Carrie told herself that she would be good. She only really ate a lot when she was with them anyway. Having so much fun with Shelby, Flo and Dillon made it easy for her to indulge a little bit. Not to mention all the wine—God she’d been drinking a lot lately. The fact that she rarely had to pay for anything while they were around made it even more rational for her, in the heat of the moment, to take just about everything that was given to her.

“I promise I’ll pay you back.” She’d say

“Don’t you worry about it, honey!”

“I mean it!”

“And I mean it more!” her friends would snip, “Now you sit yourself down and enjoy.”

And Carrie would do it—the last thing she wanted to do was find herself offending any of her new friends. But looking at herself in the mirror, side-belly and all, it was becoming obvious that something had to change. She’d just found herself with a new group of friends—and the last thing she wanted to do was be known as “the Fat Friend” of that group.

The Cougars were a lousy soccer team—but none of them would have known it.

For as much bluster as there was about coming to these games to support their girls, the time that they spent actually watching the game was inconsequential. The moms were far more concerned with their own topics of various conversation, getting the best shot in of Summer (and “Kitty”, as something of an afterthought) and generally trying to have fun despite the rather dull game. The season was almost over and, rather than share in her daughter’s joy at having been spared coming to these stupid bleachers and watching this stupid game for another year, Carrie found herself quietly terrified of having this—her one “link” to the school, and therefore the strongest connection to her new friends—taken away from her.

And despite her vow to “be good”, Carrie found herself about a foot deep into a feel-better chili dog splurge.

“Oh hun, you really do like those dogs.” Dillon laughed from behind her sunglasses, “Want me to get you another one?”

“Mm… no thank you.” Carrie mumbled, chili dotting the corners of her mouth, “I’m good.”

“Oh come on—you can’t come to a soccer match and not support the school!” Shelby crooned, picking out her clutch, “Flo, honey, go buy us all a round of chili dogs. My pin number is 84422.”

Carrie could only watch as the shortest of their quartet stood and climbed up the bleachers, heading towards the concession stand. She wanted to say no so badly, but Flo was out of earshot by the time she worked up the courage to make the word out. Even then, it’s not like Dillon or Shelby seemed to hear her. Dillon was nose-deep into her social media while Shelby was rummaging through her bag.

“Now, I know it’s a little late on account of it being the end of the season and all…” Shelby said, pushing the bag behind her back, “But me and the girls chipped in and got you a little something.”

“You… you did?” Carrie swallowed, “You guys didn’t have to—”

“Oh, but we did!” Dillon smiled, wrapping one long tanned arm around the shorter brunette, “We know it’s been real hard on you, moving into town, getting to know everyone. Not having any friends.”

Hurtful, but true. Shelby shot her friend a dirty look at the last addition to her rap sheet of Carrie’s problems, but the poor woman couldn’t argue. Other than her three friends and her daughter, Carrie didn’t have much in the way of a social life. All the more reason that she kept letting little comments like that slide more and more as of late.

“So, we wanted to show y’all that you’re one of us.” Shelby continued where her taller friend had left off, “And we got you… this!”

Whipping her arms out in front of her, Carrie was blinded by a flash of gold. In her hands, pinched between her perfectly manicured fingers, was a sports jersey that matched the uniforms of the soccer players down on the field below. And on the back was Number 5—Wright printed in white collegiate letters across the nape and breadth of the shoulders. Aside from the number, it was just like the one they all wore to every game!

“Oh my God.” Carrie gasped, taking it in her hands like the jersey was made of glass, “You guys… did this for me?”

“I had it done in my shop.” Dillon said with a smile, seeing her handiwork on display, “It’s only fair that Kittyhawk gets to see her number up in the stands too.”

“Go ahead and try it on!” Shelby said with a wicked smile, “See how it fits!”

Carrie wasted no time in downing what remained of her chili dog in order to free up her hands. Her cheeks bulging with pork and sauce, the plumping mom of one threw the jersey over her head. She was so excited, so touched by the sentiment, that she hardly noticed how hard it was to pull the damn thing over her head. Her chest caught it and distorted the 05 hard enough, but then it met her belly. Rolling it down like a condom over her fattened gut flesh, Carrie grunted at the effort it took.

“Oh noooo…” Dillon winced, “Bless your heart.”

“It… it fits!” Carrie lied, her smile wide and hopeful that it didn’t look as bad as it felt, “Right?”

“Mmm… not really, hun.” Shelby clicked her tongue, “Dillon must have ordered it a little too small…”

Carrie felt her heart drop. Here she was, sitting with the best friends that a single mother could ask for, and they’d done something really nice for her, and she’d gone and gotten too fat to wear it right. This was so embarrassing! Her belly was too big to wear the jersey that they had special ordered for her to support her daughter. God, this was the worst. A wakeup call if there ever had been one.

“How about this—you wear it today, and I’ll swap it out for a larger size tomorrow. First thing.” Dillon said with a tender touch of Carrie’s arm as it bulged from the hole, “I’ll have it to you by Thursday at the latest.”

“Oh… oh no, I don’t want you to go to any more trouble.” Carrie smiled, already working on uncurling the poor thing stuck beneath her belly, “This was really sweet. I’ll… I’ll just wear it to sleep in.”

“Oh shush, hun, it’s no trouble at all.” Shelby said with a sip of her Pepsi, “Can we at least get a picture? Dillon, honey, take our picture.”

Taking Shelby’s phone with a devious little grin, the tall brunette mother let Shelby lean in close to Carrie. Their waists side by side, decent angle, downward shot. Compared to Shelby, Carrie looked like a total cow—her hips and thighs were wide, and her belly was round. With the tightness of her shirt, you could even see where her tummy rolled up to the waistband of her jeans! Oh, Shelby would like this…

“Dillon, you want one?” Shelby asked, “Carrie, take a picture with Dillon.”

Next to Dillon, Carrie looked so short and chubby. Being so tall, even a little lanky, Dillon would make anyone look a bit round. What with her pronounced and prominent features. But Carrie looked like a hobbit among men next to her—as in, particularly short and plump by comparison.

“Ooh, did y’all give her the thing? We hope you like it sweetie!” Flo crooned, coming back and dispensing the chili dogs to her friends, “Here, lemme get a photo too.”

And even though Flo’s round pixie features helped set her apart from the domestic Shelby and the Roman Dillon, even she looked picturesque next to poor Carrie. The woman was practically busting out of her jeans. The addition of the chili dog, a playful shot of both of them opening wide for their first bite, did little to stunt the image of Carrie being a woman somewhat obsessed with food.

“Now one with us all together!” Shelby smirked, handing the phone to another bored (but decidedly less cool) mother in the stands, “Say cheese!”

They knew what they were doing, the three of them. And putting all of them together, in one photo like that, it was hard to argue with the results. Despite the fact that they were all in their late thirties, getting older, their metabolisms slower. Despite the fact that they might have put on some comfort weight, and despite the unflattering fit of the jerseys… there was no denying that Carrie made the three of them look thin.

Every group has a fat friend—one that makes everyone look better by comparison, even accidentally.

Shelby, Flo, and Dillon had managed to find theirs.

1111111111.content:
It hadn’t taken much convincing to get Flo and Dillon on board with the idea.

Much like Shelby, they were both compulsively obsessed with image. They were the cool moms that everyone wanted to be and/or lay. The kinds of women that other women’s husbands fantasized about in private. Public faces in their daughters’ school, at every event and the top of the list in every who’s-who of high school parents. While Shelby had the added benefit of a particularly insensitive and chauvinistic husband, the allure of having someone around to distract the at-a-glance from Flo and Dillon’s less-than-ideal features—slight crow’s feet with matching laugh lines and a nose that sat a bit too long and wide on her face respectively—wouldn’t have been entirely wasted on them either.

As an added benefit, it was simply something to do. A little game that the three of them could play. Something else that they could talk about amongst themselves and only amongst themselves. It was like another addition to the private world that they’d created for themselves.

“Carrie, honey, do you want some more pizza?” one of them would ask on Friday nights

“Oh, I shouldn’t…” Carrie would belch into her fist, “I’m trying to lose weight.”

“You’re right, Carrie, we should probably call it a night.”

“N-No, no, I’m not ready to go!” Carrie would always get squirrely, “I’ll, um… I will have another slice!”

Sometimes they would get together just the three of them, their power trio, and discuss the progress of their little project. Never in so many words, mind you. Just about how much Carrie was letting herself go, or how much she would eat at their previous meeting. How she’d put on some “winter weight” to coincide with the holidays, or some mean-spirited jabs about their friend’s increasingly ill-fitting sweaters.

But what had become an odd little hobby for her friends had become a waistline nightmare for Carrie, who was at odds with herself for letting go too fast and too far—having spent most of the holidays getting stuffed like a tick by her friends and relatives, poor Carrie entered the new year weighing more than two hundred and twenty pounds of pure chub!

For all of her antipathy for getting fat, Carrie sure was good at it. A failing metabolism as she crested past thirty-six combined with a thankless desk job that kept her on her ass all day, and very little talent in the kitchen had left her with quite round. With her friends keeping her nice and full at every opportunity, poor Carrie had little choice but to keep growing and growing and growing…

She was a cow. None of her clothes from last Winter fit her by a longshot. She couldn’t even roll up her leggings from last year! Her legs were too meaty, and her thighs too doughy. Her sweaters and even her jackets couldn’t meet across the chest—let alone that big belly she’d been growing. It had only expanded outwards in the past few months, rolling over her waist and forming two fleshy lovehandles that porked out at the sides; ugh, she was a wreck.

But that wasn’t the worst part—her poor face! It wasn’t enough that she was getting fat, but Carrie looked like a totally different woman with all this chub in her cheeks. She had a double chin if she looked down or smiled or… well, at even the slightest provocation!

Carrie had totally let herself go—and that was why her New Year’s Resolution was to finally drop some of this weight. Carrie had been thinking about joining a gym long before all this. She’d driven past it every day since the move on her way to work, telling herself that one day she’d go in and sign up. But as the pounds crept on and she became more enthused about hanging out with her friends than her personal fitness, the thought slowly worked its way further and further into the back of her mind. The New Year’s special that they had going on, added with the fact that she now had officially porked up past two hundred pounds, had finally helped her pull into the parking lot and sign up.

But she couldn’t exactly go at this alone…

“A gym membership?” the pit of Shelby’s stomach had dropped another inch as soon as she’d heard her designated fat friend say those three dreadful words, “Well… I mean… well…”

“Good for you, hun.” Dillon had been the one to raise her mimosa in a nonplussed sort of way “New year, new you.”

“Exactly.” Carrie said with a miles-wide smile that made her rounded cheeks bunch, “I figured it’d be something we could all do together!”

“Together.”

“Well, you girls get to do things during the day that I don’t get to because of my job.” Carrie gestured vaguely to the three of them, “And I feel like now that soccer season is over, I don’t get to see you guys a lot. So…”

Shelby winced, stress-popping a bonbon into her mouth and chasing it with a swig of champagne. The thought of losing her special project—of Carrie having a comeback story, getting her figure back—flashed before her eyes. All of the food and wine she’d poured into this pig wouldn’t be worth anything if she managed to sweat it off!

“Oh honey, that’s so cute.” Flo tittered, already a little soused after a hard day at the Art Gallery, “Don’t you worry sweetie, I’ll be your gym buddy.”

“You will?” Carrie cooed hopefully

“You will?” Shelby groused in equal parts confusion and derision

“Of course I will.” Flo preened, taking a chocolate for herself, “Once a week won’t kill me.”

Carrie’s hope crested a bit at that. Going once a week wasn’t going to do much to work off all of the unsightly pounds and inches she’d accrued in the past year. Despite having made the promise to be Gym Buddies sometime around the middle of January, it had taken three additional weeks for the two women to set foot in the doors of their local Planet Fitness.

Their first Tuesday was spent in Target, trying on components that would hopefully form the all-important workout ensemble. With Caramel Apple Spice and Salted Caramel Mochas in hand, Carrie and Flo spent two hours in their local department store wriggling in and out of tight spandex, lycra, and leggings—a less than stellar time for Carrie, who had ballooned up so much that she had to shop in an entirely different section than her petite blonde friend.

No matter what she tried on, Carrie looked like a balloon. Her stomach swelled over every waistband, pushed into every zipper, and swelled underneath every top. It looked like she’d stuffed a pillow down her shirt! Looking at herself in the changing room mirrors, all chubby and popping out of clothes she’d picked the wrong size of… it was less motivating and more humiliating. Especially because Flo insisted on a fashion show with every outfit. While her tiny friend sat on the bench outside the plus-sized section’s fitting rooms sipping coffee and munching on scones, Carrie was feeling about two inches tall and two miles wide.

They hadn’t bought anything that second week because Flo couldn’t decide on what to wear. So, the second week had been spent ordering their workout clothes online.

Carrie had driven over to Flo’s impressive condo—an old mill converted into trendy apartments that only the well-off could afford to even think about owning—and the two of them spent hours getting in-depth looks at items from the view of Flo’s smart TV. They had ordered some pizza, and made some progress, and actually managed to get to the checkout screen before they wound up getting distracted. Flo’s daughter Myr—Myr, not Myrtle—came home from their studio with new pieces to exhibit.

Carrie, her belly sloshing with spirits and cheap greasy pizza, went waddling through the doorway after she’d sobered up enough to drive home; Flo assuring her on the way out the door that she’d saved all of the items they’d looked at in her cart, and she’d order them before she went to bed.

The third week, Flo confessed that she hadn’t ordered them—but what was one more week?

So, by mid-February, Carrie’s New Year’s resolution finally began in earnest.

Having put on almost twenty more pounds since Flo had agreed to be her Gym Buddy, Carrie took her first step through the doors of her local gym in a month. Tired from a long day of sitting on her butt, clacking away at keys, and suddenly very aware that she weighed almost two hundred and fifty pounds, Carrie was seriously second-guessing this whole “exercise” thing.

All eyes would be on the big, fat, recently divorced, single mother with all of her ass crammed into a gigantic pair of stupid leggings that didn’t even fit right. She’d gone and put them on before coming and that had been such a mistake—even on the car-ride over, they’d shimmied down her blubbery cheeks as they’d risen like rising dough over the back of the waistband. The only reason her belly wasn’t showing is because she’d thrown a big white t-shirt from Wal Mart over the somewhat less than conservative athletic top that Flo had ordered for her. She wasn’t about to go at this with all of her belly hanging out like some kind of pole-dancing parade float…

“You ready, hun?” Flo asked, sipping on her Caramel Apple Spice from the neighboring Starbucks

Compared to the woman next to her, Flo looked like the picture-perfect health. Short, blonde, and dressed in bright colors—all eyes would be on her, either out of appreciation, jealousy, or a desire to undress. Flo had made sure to order “matching” outfits for the two of them; Carrie’s a big, drab gray while hers was a cute and preppy chartreuse . The small amount of weight she’d managed to put on over the holidays was nothing compared to Carrie’s sheer corpulence. Her cute little butt filled out her bright green bottoms well—milfy flesh bulging out of the legs with pure sex appeal.

“I guess…” Carrie gulped, belly bouncing as she took her first brave steps towards the elliptical.

“Great!” Flo said chipperly, readying her phone, “I’ll spot you.”

“I… I don’t think you have to spot me.” Carrie said with a nervous little laugh, “There’s another machine open though, do you want to—”

“Oh, honey please, who is the expert here?” Flo took another sip, swapping out the forward-facing camera after an obligatory gym selfie, and focusing the rear-facing camera on her friend’s fat jiggly ass, “Now let’s make this quick—thirty minutes, and then I’ve got to go pick up Myr from the studio.”

Carrie, already less than enthused with the abysmal beginnings of her career as a gym rat, wasn’t exactly happy with the new limitation that Flo’s flippancy had added to their workout. But at the same time, thirty minutes was a start.

It was also, after more than two years of sabbatical from a gym, the longest time imaginable.

“Hff… pff…”

Carrie was a huffing, puffing wreck five minutes into the workout. Her muscles squealed at the exercise not even as far into the commercial break on the TVs that hung overhead. By the time they came back on, her lungs were on fire as her pace slowed down to a crawl on the machine. With every step her shirt would ride up a bit on her belly, making her awkwardly stop her pace and pick at the waistband of her ridiculously tight leggings.

“You can do it, honey!”

Flo cheered, video focusing on Carrie’s gelatinous booty wobbling with every step

It was only worse when it rode up in the back—Carrie flashed Flo with her striped pink panties more than once. Her nails—manicured and sharpened last week at Flo’s behest—pierced the drum-tight fabric when she tried to hike it back up her ass. Two quarter-sized holes of pale butt blubber shone in the awkward fluorescent lighting of the gym, the rest of her wobbling pathetically on the elliptical as she struggled to keep a momentum going.

“You got this, sweetie!” Flo downed her sugary drink and took a bite of her granola bar from her gym bag, “Witness the fitness!”

“Hn…hhffnnn…”

Ten minutes in, and Carrie was spent. But she hung out for another five minutes, an action that she came to regret. Her leg muscles—atrophied by her desk job and sedentary habits—were wobbly and weak as soon as they hit the ground. She was red-faced, her brown hair matted and slick with sweat. The poor thing looked like a freshly misted tomato from the neck-up.

“What’s the matter, honey?” Flo crooned after having shared the highlights of the last fifteen minutes to their private chat concerning Carrie, “You’re not gonna call it quits already are you?”

“I… I can’t do it.” Carrie puffed, wiping the slick sweat from her forehead with one thick arm, “It’s too hard…”

Flo clicked her tongue sympathetically, patting Carrie on the moist shoulder. God this woman was a real heifer. She couldn’t do fifteen minutes on the elliptical—how mortifying.

“That’s alright honey, first steps are always the hardest.” Flo clucked vapidly, “You tried.”

“I… I did.” Carrie puffed, her second wind wouldn’t return for some time, “And… and there’s always next week, right?”

“That’s exactly right.” Flo crumpled up the wrapper to her granola bar and tossed it idly near the trash can, “Next week you’ll get the whole thirty in. I’ll make sure of it.”

“You’re… phew… you’re the best.” Carrie wheezed, “Sorry to… drag you out here for… ugh… fifteen minutes of my fat ass on an elliptical.”

“Don’t apologize for nothin’, honey. We’re friends~” Flo gave her fleshy friend a tight squeeze around the waist, palming a handful of backfat on her way down, “Now, what do you say we do another Starbucks run, huh? I think you’ve earned a treat after all that hard work.”

“I…” Carrie’s brow furrowed, the thought of working off whatever she had only to add on twice that didn’t sound very efficient—even to her, “I don’t know, Flo. Don’t you have to go pick up Myr?”

“Oh, she just texted me—her daddy’s gonna get her.” Flo lied, knowing full and well Myr was at her boyfriend’s house, “Ooh, here’s an idea; we’ll go get Starbucks, cool off for a little bit, and then we’ll have a nice little cheat day and get something really nice for ourselves. Doesn’t that sound fun?”

“Yeahhh…” Carrie puffed, grunting as she bent over to grab her gym bag, “I mean, we’re gonna come back next week, right? What’s the harm?”

“That’s right, honey.” Flo opened the door for her friend to lumber through, “What’s the harm?”

“Thanks again for helping me and D.W. out, darlin’.” Dillon’s sultry voice came after the oven’s overhead fan finally stopped, “I can’t tell you how much this stupid bake sale means to her.”

Katie would be catching a ride home on Tuesdays now, more than likely with Shelby’s girl, thanks to Dillon’s daughter’s bright idea for a bake sale to help raise funds for Milton High’s cheer team. D.W. Duncan was just as entrepreneurial (not to mention leggy and gorgeous) as her mom, but it had become apparent after just one attempt that she had not inherited Dillon’s baking prowess. According to her, the poor thing had been inconsolable until Dillon had agreed to help—but with so many responsibilities like the screen-printing business and getting together with her friends, just being a mom really, Dillon found herself in over her head baking for an entire club!

So Carrie, being a good friend, naturally volunteered to help! Anything for her new best friends, right?

“Oh please, you’re a guest in our house.” Dillon had said, steering Carrie’s sizable caboose towards the head of the table, “I can handle all of the bakin’ parts, I just need some help figurin’ out if it tastes any good!”

“Can’t you just… I mean, not that I’m not happy to help but…” Carrie gulped, looking at the intimidating army of cakes and cookies and pies that seemed to stare her own over a Battle of the Bulge, “…where’s D.W.? Shouldn’t she be helping?”

“That poor girl’s much better at eatin’ cookies than she is at baking them.” Dillon grunted a bit as she struggled with the surprisingly pretty pink apron, “And I’ve worked too hard slimmin’ her down just so she could fall off the wagon and go back to bein’ Double Wide Duncan.”

“Uh-huh.” Carrie nervously chewed on a chocolate peanut butter cookie, “I mean, I know I’ve started going to the gym and everything buuut…”

“Which is why I figured I’d ask for your help—give y’all a little cheat day!”

“…but Flo’s not here.”

Dillon huffed in a practiced, portioned sort of way. She’d been thinking up this little scheme for about as long as Flo had been cooking up hers. D.W. had gone and signed up for the Bake Club, and there really was a drive going on at school. But the fact of the matter was that this was just another excuse to have a nice night in with some sweets. A little treat for Dillon—who hadn’t been able to enjoy herself thanks to her daughter’s rigorous diet keeping the house more or less free of anything fun to eat.

Once a week for a month, maybe two, wasn’t going to kill anyone. What’s more, it was entirely guilt free. With Carrie around to soak up the brunt of all that sugar and cream, Dillon basically had a free pass to live a little with no regrets!

And besides, D.W. could always have the runoff for her Bake Club, whatever Dillon and Carrie couldn’t finish.

“No no!” Carrie panicked, taking Dillon’s bait like she knew that she would, “I’m just, uh… sorry she’s gonna miss out!”

Carrie grimaced at about ten thousand calories of desserts on the dinner table.

“It looks so good!” Carrie’s smile was pained as she thought of all the trips to the gym this was going to take to burn off, “Yaay…”

“I can’t tell y’all how much I appreciate this.” Dillon felt her chest flutter in excitement as she pulled another pie out of the fridge, “It means so much to me to have this chance… to, um, help my daughter.” Dillon cut two (big, big) slices and placed them on surprisingly dainty-looking plates, “We’ve got a lot of work to do, and everything’s gotta be perfect…”
