Carrie didn’t understand why she kept gaining weight.

In about a year’s time, she had put on more than a hundred pounds—that just wasn’t normal! She knew that sitting on her butt all day at her job wasn’t exactly cohesive to a healthy lifestyle, she’d been going to the gym for almost a month now and had seen no results. Thirty minutes (more or less) a week wasn’t a lot, but certainly she should have seen some results by now!

After she crested past two-fifty and eeked her way up to two-sixty, she had even roped her friends in on helping her slim down. At her behest, Shelby had started buying “lo-cal” wines to stock their little nights in, and she’d done her best to cut out all of the butters and cheeses from her home cooked meals, replaced them with margarine. They’d even switched to Diet Coke instead of sweet tea at mealtimes. Everyone had been so helpful in trying to trim Carrie back down to a manageable size, but the poor thing just kept getting fatter and fatter…

“Here, it’s better for you to snack on these than nothing at all.” Dillon had said, handing her friend what she had claimed to be off-brand (actually repackaged) double-stuf’d Oreos, “We’re going to snack—I mean, it’s only normal. But this way you don’t have to starve yourself…”

And sure, she still had her cheat days. It wouldn’t have been fair to amputate the fun from their little get-togethers just because Carrie was afraid of turning into a parade float. So, they still had pizza on Fridays. Lots of it. And Flo had talked her into switching to soy milk instead of almond at their Starbucks runs, so it’s not like her coffee even counted as a “cheat” anymore! It was probably healthier than whatever they had at the office, so getting it on her lunch breaks wasn’t the worst thing in the world…

“Oh honey, I can’t make it to the gym today. Myr needs her mama tonight.” Flo’s little orange message bubble said on Carrie’s touchscreen, “We’ll go extra hard next week though! ”

Okay, so she didn’t go to the gym every week, but Carrie couldn’t go without her Gym Buddy. She tried it once and Flo pitched such a bitch about it. It had made her feel so bad, and Shelby and Dillon acted so weird around her for the next week after… she just wished that Flo would take going to the gym as she did her little “cheats” after their workout. Carrie had only finished a thirty-minute set exactly once before Spring rolled around the corner.

Despite her best efforts, all Carrie seemed to be doing was getting fatter.

At least she had her friends to lean on when she needed them.

“Bless your heart—I always start to feel a little down on myself when I put on a little weight.” Dillon clicked her tongue meanly as she helped herself to another piece of sweet cornbread, “I know exactly what you’re going through, darlin’.”

Sitting on the vintage lounge in Shelby’s sitting room, Carrie looked every inch of the “Fat Mom” that she felt. Her other friends could no longer sit beside her—the carefully crafted balance of Shelby on the left, Dillon on the right, with Flo and Carrie in the center had shifted as Carrie continued to get bigger. Now, it was Dillon and Flo on the right, Shelby stuck on the left (she liked to lay out) and then big fat Carrie Cooleyfinger clogging up the couch right in front of the fireplace. Eat Drink & be Merry scribbled over her head as the old piece of furniture whined at every one of her heavy shifting motions.

“Here honey, have a drink.” Shelby said as she shuffled past the coffee table, serving platter in hand, “You sound like you’ve had a hard day.”

Grunting a bit as she sat up, Carrie grabbed at the stem of Shelby’s low-calorie wine. She gulped it down like it was nothing and helped herself to a few of the grapes that sat on the vine for decoration. They sat heavy on the especially buttery (sorry, margarine-y—"it’s healthier!”) dinner and what had to have been at least half a dozen pieces of cornbread. God, when had she turned into such a stress eater?

“Maybe you’re just fighting your natural shape?” Flo bit into a cupcake and took a glass of wine from the tray, “My husband’s sister is a big girl too, and she just can’t seem to lose any weight bless her heart.”

A big girl. Carrie was officially a big girl. God, this was humiliating. It was all she could do to not just down the whole wine cabinet right then and there. Every time she moved this stupid couch creaked. Creak, creak, creak, right under her big fat ass. She tried her best to sit perfectly still—to scrunch herself up as small as she could get. To stay as quiet as possible and just get the night over with.

“Uh oh, Carrie’s in a mood.” Shelby snorted into her drink, kicking her thick ivory legs up on the couch, “Nobody talk to Carrie.”

“I’m not in a mood.” The biggest, roundest woman in the world snipped, “It’s just… I’ve never been a… a big girl before. No one in my family is—”

“Honey, please, it’s normal for some women to put on a little weight as they get older.” Flo touched Carrie’s big fat knee with one hand, “So you’re a little fluffy, who cares? We for sure don’t.”

“Yeah, I mean look at Shelby.” Dillon snorted

“More cake Dillon?” Shelby hissed, pushing the platter of pastries (made by the school’s bake club) towards her friend, “Put your mouth to some use other than sucking off pool boys and general bitchery?”

“Don’t mind if I do.” Dillon purred, leaning forward to pluck a profiterole, “Mm, these are good.”

“Carrie should have some.” Flo rocked herself up one and leaned over, one gooey treat between her forefinger and thumb, “Go on, hun, they’re delicious.”

Carrie had spent the better part of last year (and all of this year) making such a pig out of herself that her first instinct was to grab the doughy little snack that bulged between Flo’s fingers. A little voice in the back of her head nagged at her constantly, bitching to her about her weight. With the whimpering couch beneath her acting as a backup singer, Carrie had a full chorus of concerns telling her that the last thing she needed was a profiterole.

Even still, her mouth moistened. She had had such a shitty day—such a shitty week really, and getting wine drunk with her friends was the only solace that she’d had lately. She was already so big, what was one more little, teeny cake going to do that she hadn’t done to herself this whole past year?

“I… I guess…” Carrie panted, smacking her lips a little, “Here, lemme just…”

Carrie had sat too far back in the couch. She had to scoot up to reach past her belly, and that meant dragging her especially ample ass across the old creaking couch. Struggling to reach forward, a fat girl grunt of exertion falling out of her gaping mouth, a final and definitive CRACK filled the sitting room.

“Oh God.” Carrie said a flat terror, “Guys… what was that?”

“I… think that was the couch.” Dillon scrunched her face in concern

“That did not sound good.” Shelby commented, refilling her glass of red wine, “Carrie, honey, are you okay?”

“I’m fine, just… let me…” Profiterole between her fingers, Carrie slowly, very slowly leaned back into place on the couch, “Lean in here…”

And all at once, the old sofa came tumbling to the ground. The bottom fell out as the legs buckled at the joists. Carrie was sent tumbling down to the hardwood, screaming in confusion and surprise. Carrie had fallen through the bottom of the lounge, busted the support at the legs, and landed butt-down on the ground!

“Oh my Lord.” Shelby could barely contain herself—a mean-spirited guffaw broke through the charade of friendship, watching the spectacle, “Carrie, you broke the couch!”

Carrie’s big green eyes began to water as the reality of the situation dawned on her. She… she was really fat. Couch-breakingly enormous. She knew that she’d been putting on weight. She knew that she’d been cutting corners and her diet wasn’t the best. Sure, working out once a week for thirty-ish minutes wasn’t going to turn her into a supermodel but she shouldn’t… she couldn’t…

Why was this happening to her? Among everything else that was wrong in her life, with the divorce and the crappy job and the moving and the single parenting, why was she blowing up like a parade float on top of it all?!

“Oh, oh honey.” Flo clicked her tongue, in a passing moment of sympathy, “Don’t feel bad. These—these are old couches, right Shelby?”

“Snrt! Right.” Shelby said through barely-restrained laughter, “It’s the couches. They’re—ha!—super old and… flimsy!”

“R-Right…” Carrie sniffled, a hot tear rolling down her chubby cheek “I… I think I’m gonna call it early tonight ladies.”

“Here darlin’, lemme help you up.” Dillon said with a hint of remorse face, struggling to straighten herself up, “Lemme just… just…”

And in a moment that didn’t negate, but certainly helped ease the pain and embarrassment of what she had just gone through, a now-familiar sound pierced through the sitting room and cracked over Carrie’s whimpering. Whether it was because she sat up too fast, maybe spread her legs too wide, or just a combination of age and added weight between the other couch’s two occupants, another loud CRACK filled the room, and both Dillon and Flo found themselves on the floor with Carrie.

“See?” Shelby smirked to herself in a satisfied sort of way as she watched her friends wriggle around on the floor, popping a double stuf’d Oreo in her mouth, “I told you Carrie—flimsy.”

The Night of the Shattered Couches would not go down as one of Carrie’s finest moments—from that incident onward, the sheer scope of Carrie’s weight problem really seemed to dawn on her.

Before, Carrie was just aware that she’d been putting on weight. At a very rapid pace, yes, but it wasn’t a real threat. There were no corporeal consequences to her size, only emotional. She was fat, she felt like crap about it, but the worst thing that had come from it all was having to buy new clothes and some less-than-stellar workout routines at the gym. The emotional toll was heavy, yes, but it all paled in comparison to the realization that she was so heavy that she’d gone and busted the couch. Even if Flo and Dillon had done the same not long after she had—even if the couches were old—it still took two skinnier women to do what one Big Fat Carrie could do.

She’d done her best to stay in a good humor about it, but the fact was that the bottom of Carrie’s guts had fallen out along with that couch. She was a wreck about it—and everyone could see it.

“Hey mom?” Katie rapped politely on her mother’s bedroom door, “I’m, um… I’m headed out. You need anything?”

“No thanks.” Carrie grouched, a giant lump underneath the covers, “Just lock up before you leave.”

“Okay…” Katie shut the door to just a crack, “Love you.”

All of Carrie’s desire to go out and have fun with her friends had been replaced with nothing other than a desire to clog up the hole farthest away from society and die in it. Her nights, once spent with drinking and dinners and going out on the town, were quickly and quietly replaced with nights in on the couch. Or in bed. Almost always with food.

For as much as she hated being big enough to bust furniture, the only thing that seemed to make her feel better was food. Lots of it. From every angle of the Takeout Food Pyramid. McDonalds, Bojangles, Hardee’s, Taco Bell, Little Caesar’s… anything and everything on the way home. She’d squeeze herself into the car, roll up to the drive-thru window, and prattle off one course before grabbing another at yet another hut, house, or takeout option otherwise.

Predictably, this only served to hasten her weight gain. Carrie seemed to be good at that. Her girth only grew once she got even less exercise than what she’d managed to stuff into her routine when she would hang out with her friends. And not having something to drink all the time only served to make her hungrier. In shying away from her friends out of shame, she was only making her problem that much worse.

And believe it or not, Katie wasn’t the only person who was concerned.

“I’m worried about Carrie.” Flo said one Friday night over pizza, “It’s been two weeks since I’ve talked to her.”

“And it’s been a month since she crushed that couch.” Dillon pursed, “You think she’s okay?”

“Who cares?” Shelby rolled her eyes, “More pizza for us.”

Food had slowly become a staple in their little get-togethers. Every time they met, sat, or drank there was always something to nibble on. It was, at first, meant entirely for Carrie in hopes of leading her down the road into further Fat Friend territory. The woman was always snacking on something, and it was hard to remember a time when there wasn’t something to eat and drink nearby whenever they came over to Shelby’s. Even now, three weeks since the roly-poly brunette had set foot through the door, the habit was hard to break. Just as much food, one less mouth to feed.

Shelby laid out on the bigger, more modern looking chaise. It didn’t go as well with the ambiance of the room, but it was a much more hip and angular style. White, dark blue, and lime green pleather all around the matching quartet of couches, each with a thin red stripe going along the back that wrapped along the armrests. They even had footrests built into the bottoms (a feature Shelby was most pleased with) and boasted a capacity weight of over one thousand pounds.

Shelby snickered at the thought of Carrie somehow managing to bust through one of these babies, her belly blubber bobbing in bemusement.

“Shelby, hun, aren’t you even a little worried about her?” Flo winced, dipping her breadstick in garlic butter, “I mean… it’s kinda our fault she got so big…”

“We never made her eat nothin’.” Shelby sniffed derisively, “That heifer ballooned up all by her lonesome—and cost me a perfectly good couch, by the way.”

It had been Katie who talked her mother into accepting the invitation to go hang out with the other moms. She’d been doing her best to be a supportive daughter throughout the whole ordeal—from the beginnings of the divorce to her mother’s worrying weight gain and her sudden crash. Seeing her mom change so much, so soon, had really worried her. It was the least she could do to try and talk her into putting on something other than sweatpants.

“Remember what you told me before you made me join the soccer team?” Katie had put her hands on her hips, “You can’t just sit around all day, like a big couch potato?”

“I know, or I’ll grow eyes.” Carrie exhaled, her cheeks inflating even further as a jetstream of petulant air escaped her, “Don’t use my Mom Answers against me, you turd.”

And so, that was what brought Carrie Cooleyfinger to the front door of Shelby Sullivan’s impressive plantation house for the first time in a month. All of the initial trepidation that she’d felt that first time, the day of the Pool Party last year, had returned to her threefold. The last time she’d seen these women, she’d made a complete clown out of herself. It had been so embarrassing, and she was just so… so tired of being fat.

But Katie was right—she couldn’t just sit around and eat her troubles away. The extra twenty pounds she’d put on attested enough to that.

Carrie was huge. A great big ball of a woman. Her stomach hung over her crotch, sinking low as it divided into two distinct tiers of top and bottom. The top half was larger—she looked like she was wearing a tire as a sports bra. Her arms rested neatly on a cushion of fat and hung at an angle, her pillowy chest rolling with the spherical shape she’d accrued. Her neck and chin had more or less become one entity; she had a swaddling deposit of fat that creased into two chins to make up for the merger.

Bulging out from underneath the hem of her biggest floral top, about an inch of belly blubber made itself shown in the form of a milky white smile of chub that shimmied as she hefted herself up the stairs. She’d squeezed herself into an industrial pair of stretchy jeans that she hadn’t outgrown yet but could no longer button over her belly.

“Hey sugar!” Flo wiggled her fingers playfully, “Oh, it’s so good to see you!”

The smaller blonde wrapped herself around Carrie’s corpulence as best she could manage. This might have been the first time that Flo had hugged Carrie first. Her friend pressing herself against her was just about what Carrie needed at the moment. She wrapped her meaty arms around the chubby blonde woman and pressed her tight.

“It’s good to see you too, Flo.” Carrie said sweetly, “I missed you guys.”

“Oh, we missed you too, hun.” Flo gave an appreciative peck on Carrie’s chubby cheek, “We’ve got everything ready in the sitting room.”

“Everything ready” had been something of an understatement, Carrie would find as she braved the climb up the stairs for the first time in a month. The walk had left her winded as usual, her flabby legs already aching with having to heave her heft up all those steps. But at the sight of what was waiting for her in the waiting room, she could hardly wait to brave a few more if it meant getting inside.

All of her favorites—all of the staples of their little get-togethers—had been spread out about the room. Boxes of pizza, Krispy Kreme donuts, gallons of sweet tea, bottles of wine, a couple of biscuits from Bojangles. Her friends had really gone all out for her!

Shelby had been laid out on her new chaise when Carrie came through the front door, two bites into a boberry biscuit. While she hadn’t exactly been all warm and fuzzy about getting Carrie back in their good graces, she wasn’t about to pass up the chance to play hostess, or to see how fat that cow had gotten on her own. Seeing her a good twenty pounds heavier only reassured Shelby that she hadn’t done a thing wrong and assuaged her concerns about the extra inches of cuddle-fluff hiking up her dress.

“Carrie, it’s so good to see you!” Dillon greeted her standing, wrapping her long arms over Carrie’s shoulders as she battled against her boulder-sized belly, “We were so worried.”

“You were not.” Carrie preened as she drank in the hug, “You were not worried about li’l ol’ me.”

“We were!” Shelby managed a smile as she rolled onto her feet, “The party just isn’t the same without our Care Bear!”

Taking her first glass from the hostess and waddling over to what was to be her couch for the evening (“it’s new, and they’re so comfortable!”) Carrie found herself feeling much more at home this time around. No creaking couches, no snarky comments… her friends seemed so happy to see her!

And all of this food, just waiting for her to tuck into…

Carrie was more than a little distracted.

“Carrie, honey, we wanted to talk to you.” Flo started, her fingers pressed together over a fat belly, “We… haven’t exactly been the best friends.”

“You seemed pretty upset about what happened with the, uh…” Dillon clicked her tongue soberly, “The couches. And we didn’t really make more of an effort to reach out to you.”

“We know that your life is a little harder than ours…”

“With the divorce and the single parenting.”

“And we just wanted to let you know that we care about you. And we’re going to do our best to make you feel like you’re part of our little group again.” Flo chirped, her hands unfolding laterally, “Which is why we got to talking about something we could all do together, all the time, every week.”

“After five ‘o’ clock, naturally.”

“Which is why we decided…” Flo did a dramatic little drumroll that reverberated in her chubby chest, “Diet Buddies!”

In all honesty, this had been a Come to Jesus moment behind the scenes. Flo and Dillon had basically had to talk Shelby into actually trying to lose weight instead of relying on Carrie to make her look thinner by comparison. They’d wrestled with it all week, feeling miserable about how they’d treated Carrie up until that fateful Couch Incident. And since they’d all agreed that they’d gotten a little pudgy lately, this seemed like the best solution.

They explained a version of that to Carrie, who sat in her seat taking it all in. They couldn’t come clean about the whole “Fat Friend” thing, but they could at least share that they’d really come to like her. Nothing was said about intentionally bailing on the gym or making sure that there was always food to snack on, but “I wasn’t the best Gym Buddy” and “We probably didn’t make it easy for you to stick to a diet” were close substitutions.

Everybody wins! Carrie gets to have friends, Flo and Dillon didn’t have to feel like shit, and everyone got to lose weight after one last hurrah before getting their bodies back!

“So, what do you say?” Flo smiled hopefully, “One last pig-out before we start dieting for real?”

“You guys…” Carrie smiled, her cheeks dimpling twice over, “You don’t need to do that to yourselves for me—I’m okay.”

“…I’m sorry?”

“It’s sweet that you’re worried about me, but… I’m okay with who I am.” Carrie smiled serenely, taking a piece of pizza from the box closest to her, “I think, as long as I have friends like you guys to support me… I’ll be okay no matter what size I am!”

“Really?” Shelby piqued an amber eyebrow, piping up for the first time during this stupid little love-fest, “You hear that, guys?”

“I-I mean…” Flo faltered, her speech having fallen flat, “But the last time we saw you…”

“I know, I know, but… maybe you’re right! This is just my natural shape.” Carrie pat her belly depreciatively, “I’m never gonna be a size two anymore. And y’all look great, I don’t know why you want to diet! But… I think I’m done torturing myself over what I eat.”

Dillon and Flo looked at each other in confusion, and then at Shelby, who was smiling like the cat who ate the canary.

“I tell you what—you promise to keep inviting me over and being my friend, and I promise to keep making y’all look skinny by comparison.” Carrie snorted, “Now pass me the ranch.”

“Four chili dogs for me, please.” Carrie flashed a smile, “I’ve got a figure to keep up.”

1111112.content:
After Troy had greeted them at the door, he ushered his wife’s friend Carrie and her daughter to their seats at the table. An already uncorked bottle of red wine was there, with Shelby waiting for her friend glass in hand, as the two of them became said their hellos.

However, while Carrie was preoccupied getting to know her daughter’s new friend, Shelby had excused herself deeper into the kitchen to begin serving dinner. She’d finished her glass of wine, set it aside, and put both hands on the mashed potatoes she’d slaved over making the “right” way. No butter, no salt, no cheese. Boring as all get out—but that was just one of the ways she could keep Troy off nagging about her weight.

“Your friend’s nice.” Troy said as an aside, finishing his bottle of beer and tossing it into the trashcan by the door, “Real handsome woman, too.”

“Mm.” Shelby pursed her lips as she lifted the boring potatoes, her expression as flat and loveless as their sex life, “Eats like a cow though.”

“She might eat like a cow, but at least she puts it in the right places.” Troy said the words loosely with a little chuckle, “Nothin’ compared to yer gal Flo though—I wouldn’t kick her out of bed for eatin’ biscuits, that much is for sure.”

The synapses between Shelby’s gray matter seemed to tickle at yet another mention of one of her oldest, and apparently prettiest friends. Troy had made plenty of comments in the past before about Flo Folly—Artsy Mom of their little power trio—but to bring her up when she wasn’t even around? When she wasn’t even part of the conversation? That rubbed her through the callus and right into the raw.

“Now is that any way to talk about our guest—that she’s not as pretty as little ol’ Flo?” Shelby managed as fireworks flew behind her eyes, “If you’re not careful you might hurt somebody’s feelings.”

“Well then don’t tell her that I think Dillon’s prettier’n both of y’all put together.” Troy winked and held a finger over his lips, a little buzzed and especially loose lipped after one too many beers, “It’ll make dinner conversation real awkward.”

An angry growl escaped the stoic Southern mom as her husband slunk into the next room to play nice with Carrie. How could he be such a pig? Talking about her friends that way when all he had to say about his own wife of almost eighteen years was that she was getting fat?

Well, if he was so worried about his wife’s waistline—maybe she’d give him a better perspective. Show him what some real cows looked like…

***


“Go ahead and eat up, y’all!” Shelby said with a practiced friendliness and a subdued southern spite, worthy of any hostess on the Food Network, “I made plenty—no reason to be shy!”

No sooner than had the words left her lips that her guests of the evening started to dig in. And who could blame them? Shelby was easily the best cook out of the four of them, and she didn’t break out the kitchenware near often enough for their liking. Nobody quite knew what the bug up her butt was, but she’d gotten a real kick to play Hostess lately. She’d been inviting the girls over just about every other day for dinner, making a spread fit for a queen (or four queens, in this case) and keeping everyone’s glasses filled with sweet tea and marmalade wine.

“Thank you guys again for working around my schedule.” Carrie addressed the group as she helped herself to a heap of green beans from the dish, “I really appreciate it.”

“Oh, it’s no problem at all, Carrie honey.” Shelby pat her friend on the cheek with one long ivory hand, “Besides, I don’t think you’ll hear either of them girls over there complaining about comin’ over to Shelby’s for supper!”

The deck of the Sullivan’s plantation home was alive and well, even in the early Autumn darkness. The mason jar lights were lit, and the new patio table was fit to bust at the sizable spread of southern cooking Shelby’d loaded up. Pot roast with mashed potatoes, green beans, and a macaroni pie recipe she’d stolen from Pinterest. Still chilling in the fridge were two pies (lemon and key lime), while another basketful of biscuits cooled on the countertop in the kitchen—the whole nine yards, as far as southern get-togethers went.

What’s more, Shelby knew all of their favorites. She made plenty of them just about every night.

“Y’all are gonna need a forklift to get me outta here.” Dillon said with a little laugh as she helped herself to a mighty plop of pot roast, “Shelby’s gonna need to take out part of the fence before she’s done with us!”

“This macaroni pie is to die for, sugar~” Flo crooned after her first bite, “Carrie, honey, you want some of this?”

“Do I.” Carrie said greedily, fumbling with the plate as the wine started to hit, “I’ve never had anything this good!”

The redheaded hostess could only smile to herself, besetting a certain terrible triumph in the dimpling of her cheeks. Moving their little get-togethers to the porch had been the best idea she’d ever had. Instead of climbing up and down the stairs, keeping herself on her feet (or worse yet, her friends!), the kitchen was just a hop and a jump away. The living room was right there through the back door, too! So, when everyone was done, their bellies full of Shelby’s rich southern cooking and sloshing with wine, they could just go lay out on the long couches until their heads cleared up enough to make the drive home. And while they were there, Shelby could always count on passing out cornbread to soak up the alcohol…

“Now ain’t this so much better than that dumb ol’ sitting room?” Shelby goaded her friends, passing out biscuits in rotation, “Fresh air, lots of room to wiggle, and—”

“Great food.” Dillon said again, “I don’t understand why you ain’t been cookin’ for us like this the whole time, darlin’!”

“Well…” Shelby clicked her tongue as her smile spread across her face, “…Lots of time to make up for, then.”

11111121.content:
As strange as it sounded, Carrie gave her the perfect excuse to keep their get-togethers as late possible.

Being the only one who had a full forty-hour work week to attend to, Shelby made a pretty big fuss about including her. After all, they were friends, right? And good friends like them did everything together—it just wasn’t fair that Carrie couldn’t come because she lived in a one-income household.

That meant that just about every time they saw one another, it was dinnertime. And since Shelby was so keen on inviting everyone over, what had once been a myriad of events around town and at the school soon became just three or four blocks a week in everyone’s schedule called “Supper at Shelby’s”.

There wouldn’t be much meeting up outside of that time, either—Shelby saw to it! Sure, she and Flo would go for a coffee now and then. Anything to get her out of that dull gallery. And maybe, if she was in the area, she’d drop by Dillon’s screen-printing shop with donuts. Her friend sure appreciated the opportunity to get out of her dinky little office. Even Carrie got in a lunch at least once a week! Somewhere quick though, since she barely got an hour.

Any other time that Shelby didn’t approve, she could always whip out the now tried-and-true excuse of “Well, I was gonna get ready for dinner tonight…”

And slowly, Dillon and Flo got the message. Their days of running around the county or showing up at the school, checking out new shops or this and that in downtown were very slowly replaced with the humdrum life that they so desperately wanted to avoid—exactly why they used to spend so much time away! Being stuck in their respective workspaces all day with nothing better to do was boring. And that only served to make Supper at Shelby’s all the more important to them. It might have been a little dull but there was always so much to look forward to…

“I was thinking maybe we could go to that football game in Mauldin.” Dillon grunted as she rolled her weight onto the armrest of the couch downstairs, her round belly nestled between her thick thighs, “I know it’s a long drive, but our boys deserve the support. They’re real good this year.”

“I don’t know, hun, that sounds like a lot.” Shelby clicked, heading into the living room with a freshly cooled sheet of cookies, “And besides, Carrie’d probably have to work the next day.”

“Well, I mean, I could ask of—” Carrie’s intrusion was cut short by a cookie being popped past her lips, “Mmph!”

“Oh, we could try that new restaurant that opened up?” Flo added helpfully, setting her glass down and rubbing the taut dome of her belly appreciatively as it bubbled and churned, “That’s something we could all do in one night.”

“There’s an idea!” Shelby congratulated her porky blonde friend with a cookie, “See, that’s something we can manage.”

“I guess…” Dillon shifted in her seat, the tightness of her (now buttonless) jeans wearing angry red lines on her supple shape, “I’m just bored y’all. It just feels like we used to do a lot more, y’know? Now it’s just… I dunno, here and home games.”

Shelby cut her eyes menacingly at the oblivious Dillon. She’d been talking a bit too much about getting out and about for Shelby’s taste. Ever since she’d started this whole “fatten up her friends” thing, she hadn’t heard hide nor hair about how hot they were from her husband—she wasn’t about to let them get adventurous and slip out of her fingers. Not when she had them right where she wanted them.

“You know what you need, hun?” Shelby said sweetly, “A spa day—we’ll all have one. Carrie can come too!”

“Really?” Carrie huffing as she rolled into a sitting position, her turgid stomach bunching awkwardly, “This weekend?”

“Next weekend.” Shelby corrected, “Y’all are still coming over for drinks on Saturday, right?”

Of course they were. Shelby’s house was the place to be. And when they wobbled through the door, there would be plenty of cookies, cakes, and pies to whet their whistle with.

111111211.content:
Carrie huffed and puffed as she lugged herself up the long long long walkway that lead up to her place of work. For a job that made her spend so much time on her ass, you would have thought that they would have put the door closer to the goddamn parking lot. But instead, it only seemed like it got longer every week! Carrie knew that she was getting out of shape, but it was the days like this—where the commute from her Honda Civic to the front door left her winded—that she really told herself that she was getting too fat for her own good.

But what was the harm? Her friends were fat—God that was such a mean thing to say.

It was true, though! How could anyone expect a Southern single mother to keep her figure in a state where there were almost literally no gyms or sidewalks? It was a miracle she’d kept ahold of her figure for this long…

Even still, getting dressed for work was getting harder. Not just in finding clothes her size, but in actually dressing herself. Carrie hadn’t seen her toes in months and bending over to pull up her slacks was becoming a herculean task—even when she wasn’t still buzzed or full from the night before. All of her nights over at Shelby’s were taking their toll alright, but she was having so much with her new friends! Maybe she was getting a little round, but it wasn’t like things were out of control yet.

She’d join a gym—next month, after she’d paid the bills, of course—and maybe start skipping lunch at work. Surely that would help her shed the extra couple of… dozen pounds she’d picked up this past year?

***


Meanwhile, clear across town, the only huffing and puffing in the HVAC Art Gallery came from the locomotive exhibit upstairs. Flo Folly had spent all morning on her butt, propped up at the front desk with nothing better to do but scroll through Facebook.

Days like this made her miss when she and her friends did stuff! It had been months since she’d had to “rearrange” her schedule last minute because Shelby found something fun for them to do. For months now, it felt like she’d been staring at the art—not even the art, the white walls behind it—with nothing else to do.

Except eat, of course.

Flo’s fleshy folds bunched and rolled as she shifted awkwardly on her stool. Her ass was too big on either side to really sit comfortably on it anymore—how had it ever, with how small this damn thing was? Picking at the waistband of her leggings from the back, Flo reduced the half-foot of whale tail rolling out the back to a mere inch or two. She made a little grumble, her round face creasing in consternation, as she failed yet again to sit easily on the stool.

The roly-poly blonde was getting awfully round these days—she could see it just as plain as everyone else. With so little time spent on her feet, what had started as a milfy muffin top had exploded in what felt like overnight! Her belly hung over her nethers, wobbling all the while as her walk slowly became a waddle. With her thick, short legs and her wide hips, Flo toddled more than anything these days!

She knew that she should be cutting back, but she felt like she almost never got to see her friends anymore unless it was Shelby playing hostess—and everything just tasted sooo good…

“Just a few more hours, and then I’m done.” Flo told herself aloud, ripping into the first of two Hardee’s biscuits she’d snagged for herself before work, “At least Shelby’s will be fun tonight…”

***


And then somewhere in between was Dillon Duncan, mulling over about how the best part about being the boss—and running what was essentially an under-the-table business—was that she could pretty much do what she wanted.

And that included wearing sweatpants to work.

She had popped through her last pair of leggings last week—big creamy butt cheeks for all of Shelby’s neighbors to see when she made the fatal mistake of bending over. She’d been getting so big lately that she barely had anything to wear—jeans, slacks, leggings… she’d have even taken jeggings. But instead, all she was left with were the biggest pair of sweatpants that Target had to offer. And in an unflattering insulated gray that only served to make her hips look that much wider.

“Well, I think it’s safe to say I won’t be leaving my office today.” She remarked to herself in a resigned sort of way, grunting as she hefted her stomach out from underneath the waistband of her pants, “Perks of being the boss.”

Dillon pat her pliable flesh derisively—her bombshell figure was long gone, and now so was the fashion. The irony of working in a screen-printing shop and not being able to find clothes that fit her (and fit her well) was not lost on her.

“At least I won’t have to hold back at Shelby’s tonight.” Dillon grunted to herself, shifting on a creaking chair as she turned to her computer, “Since I’m already wearing my Fat Pants.”

1111112111.content:
Shelby almost missed the days when she and her friends would galavant around town. The old sitting room had been empty for so long it’d been dusty—and that was just the last time Shelby had set foot through the door. If you would have told her she’d be playing Southern Comfort around the time this whole thing started, she never would have believed it. But there was plenty of joy to be found in playing homemaker.

Especially when you had friends to make you look skinny by comparison. What was a little comfort weight when you had friends like hers rolling up to the dinner table almost every night?

“Hey honey—come on inside, I’ve got everything ready!”

Shelby wrapped her arms around Carrie Cooleyfinger as best she could manage—the woman was getting so big around the belly that she just sort of bumped into her. She couldn’t make her arms meet around unless she hugged that cow around the shoulder anymore, and even that was getting hard with her fat arms and all.

She’d come up to Shelby red-faced, winded from the slight incline in the Sullivan’s yard that ran up the driveway and to the porch. Her puddle cheeks red and blotchy, Carrie sputtered out a response before heading inside. For such a hard-working woman, Carrie was so eager to kick her feet up and relax in the lap of luxury that only her rich friends could provide. The poor thing never saw it coming—Shelby might have felt a little bad for her being blind sighted like this, if the circumstances had been different.

But with things as they were, Carrie was plenty happy to keep coming back—she’d never do anything to upset her friends. Least not the hand that fed her. And that meant Shelby was more than happy to keep on feeding…

Not long after Carrie had come, Flo’s vintage Volkswagen puttered up the side of the road—a four-seater that couldn’t hold anything more than Flo and her daughter as she continued to puff up and up and up…

“Hey sugar…” she gasped, wiping the sweat from underneath her bright blonde bangs, “Good to see you…”

“You too, honey.” Shelby cooed, watching the little ball of blubber waddle up the sidewalk. “Oh, you look so cute.”

Flabby Flo gasped a half-hearted thank you, loathe to admit that she’d had to special order the tent-sized dress that she’d squeezed herself into. The flower pattern distorted along the severe curvature of her gut as it swung between her meaty legs, the only piece of pattern spared was that spread across her bust. Along her mile-wide hips, Flo’s flowers were unrecognizable blobs of lycra spread thin along pasty white flesh.

She was so bottom heavy, Flo barely even waddled. Shelby could hear her thighs chafing from the front porch—how much longer until she was bigger around than she was tall? Watching her kick her legs out at an angle just to get a momentum going, her fat arms swinging stupidly at her side as her belly bobbed and weaved beneath that too-tight lycra dress, Shelby couldn’t help but think that the day was coming sooner rather than later…

“Hff… Hey… pff… Darlin’…”

Dillon was the last to arrive—her husband’s truck failing to dip as low as her shiny BMW did. Such a tall girl would have had hardly any trouble getting in and out of that monster, if she didn’t have the belly weighing her down. Dillon could hardly pick her knees up high enough to see what socks she had on, let alone heft her heifer self in and out of a Dodge without losing balance.

No doubt if she was a shorter woman, Dillon would be having a much harder time getting around than she already was. As big as could be in every sense of the word, Dillon was hit the hardest by Shelby’s scheming. Her plan to turn her friends into fatties so her husband wouldn’t look their way meant that Dillon wasn’t just Tall, she was also getting Big. Well, Bigger. And bigger and bigger and bigger…

Shelby hugged her friend tight, pressing herself into the hanging apron of Dillon’s double-tiered gut. She came up to her friend’s chest, but there was no way she could have gotten that close to the gal anymore. Not without a few lifestyle changes and a very expensive surgery.

Shelby couldn’t help but watch as her friend—a woman “twice as hot as she and Carrie put together” (as her husband had put it once) now more than enough for three women all by her lonesome. Maybe even four!

“Alrighty girls, let’s dig in—” Shelby said once all of her pawns were at the table, “—I made plenty!”

***


“More pie, y’all?”

Troy simply grunted in response, entirely too focused on his macaroni pie to have paid clear attention to what his wife had been rambling on about. Not long ago the mention of Dillon, Flo, and Carrie would have gotten his member throbbing. But now, what with how big they’d all gotten, there wasn’t any hope of that. Not like he could do much good by himself anyway.

“I don’t know how you stay so skinny, Mom.” Summer frowned, her round cheeks creasing as her double chin sank to touch her chest, “I wish I got your metabolism instead of Dad’s.”

“Oh, hush up, it’s just puppy fat.” Shelby crooned as she smacked her daughter’s rippling freckled face playfully, “Now eat up—I made plenty.”

The Sullivans were a big family. With the most important woman in their life so devoted to cooking seemingly twenty-four seven, it was no surprise! With nothing more than a desk job to keep him thin, Troy Sullivan’s former football star figure began to bloat underneath the sheer onslaught of calories his wife kept at an arm’s reach. Even their daughter—former soccer co-captain—was no match! Sluggish on the field as she was in the metabolism department, both Sullivans found themselves just as much at home at the dinner table as their frequent dinner guests…

“So.” Troy grunted, his voice thick and heavy—he was far too fat to get drunk from the two or three Bud’s he’d chugged—“After dinner, what’s say we cuddle up on the couch?”

“Maybe.” Shelby winked, buttering her husband a biscuit, “If you’re good.”

As her husband’s dick throbbed somewhere underneath that belly of his, Shelby’s heart soared in victory. Her husband was too fat to cheat. Her friends were so fat that they’d make anyone look skinny next to them. Everyone was eating out of the palm of her hand—literally at least part of the time!

Life was good. Life was great.

But it could be better.

Even if it hadn't technically been "her room" since high school, Haley hadn't once woken up with that hazy sense of unease that one got when sleeping in an unfamiliar place. If anything, she had spent more mornings back at her apartment in Charleston shaking off the feeling that she didn't quite belong there. For the past two weeks, Haley had slept like a baby and awoken contentedly in her fluffy pink comforter and her washed cotton sheets. She hadn't slept as well in the two years that she'd been away than she had in the two weeks since she'd moved back home.

"Haley!" Came a familiar cry from downstairs, "Breakfast is ready!"

She would never get tired of hearing those words. Living on her own had been hell. Exciting at times, but mostly hell. She hadn't eaten an honest, solid breakfast in years. Mostly because she was always waking up early to go to her crappy job. Most days, she wouldn't eat until noon. And it wasn't like she had the money to go out and eat all the time—rent was expensive!
Even if she would have much rather slept her day away, Haley couldn't resist the siren song of a home-cooked meal. The smoky smell of bacon and the sizzling of eggs on the pan made her mouth wet. She smacked her lips appreciatively and lumbered down the hallway as if in a trance.

Haley West had changed since she last lived at home.

When she had left she was a high school graduate, eager to live life by her own rules. Stay out as late as she wanted, hang out with her friends, and just be what she perceived as an adult. But that kind of lifestyle was expensive, and couldn't be sustained for long! Especially not without a college degree. So, she partied her way through the first few months before her roommate flaked out on her. Then she had to get another job. Then her other roommate had bailed. Her boyfriend broke up with her, so there went his $100 contribution. Then she found some new roommates on Reddit, but they were creepy. Then another one, but they didn't get along with the creepy one so they moved out... honestly, it hadn't been an easy time.

Now she was older, taller. A little taller, anyway. Her hair was its natural color again and she had started dressing like an adult. No more expensive band t-shirts, but she was still stylish. Usually. Not now, of course. Haley's cute little bob was curly and uncontrollable from all the deep snuggling she'd done into her pillow. Her eyes still had sleep in them, and she hadn't done her makeup yet.

But hey, it wasn't like her mom cared.

"There she is—my little college student!" Haley's mom practically cooed like a dove as her daughter dragged herself through the kitchen, "How'd you sleep?"

"Pretty good." Haley smacked her lips, "What time is it—eight, nine?"

"More like ten thirty." The older woman said with a pat of her precious daughter's cheek, "I figured you needed to get your rest."

"Mom, I told you I was going to try to get a job today." Haley exhaled nasally, "I asked you to wake me up super early."

"And I told you I don't even want to hear the word "job" until you're sure you can handle the pressures of being in college." Mrs. West said with a stern, but gentle tone, "Now sit. I made your favorites."

Without any further hesitation, Haley sat.

Before her laid the same spread that had greeted her every morning since she had told her mother that she wanted to move back in. Bacon, eggs, pancakes, sausage, and biscuits straight from the tube. There used to be muffins, but there were only so many to a box. After two years of living off of ramen noodles, sandwiches, and dollar menu items, Haley wasn't exactly one to complain. Even after two weeks, she hadn't said so much as a word against the prodigal daughter treatment.

Picking up her fork and starting to saw into her pancakes, Haley was happy to oblige her mother's newfound appreciation for having her around.

"You want some syrup?" Her mom asked, touching the table slightly, "Let me get you some syrup. You want the blueberry kind, right?"

"Heck yeah." Haley chuckled, "Lay it on me, mama."

Haley watched the sticky blue sweetener flow from the bottle like water from a pitcher and onto her fluffy flapjacks. Her mom had started her off with a stack of two every morning ever since she had gotten back, but today's plate was a little taller than usual.

"Hey, what's with the extra story on my pancake platter?" Haley asked, picking up where she left off

"Well, you kept asking for seconds." Her mother placed the bottle of syrup back in the cabinet, "I figured that it'd save time to just give you another pancake—I'm a mother, I notice things."

Haley bit into her first forkful of pancake—three layers of fluffy flapjack coated in blue sticky goo. She gnashed and chewed her mouthful, before noticing something warm between each layer.

"Did you put butter between all my pancakes?" Haley asked with a wry smile and half a mouth full of dough

"Just how you like them." Mrs. West winked, "I figured you deserved a special treat since you start your first day of college tomorrow."

"It's not that big a deal." The bobbed brunette rolled her eyes dismissively, "I'm just going for a business degree. Tara's already got hers."

"And she would have gotten hers faster if she was here instead of living on campus." Mrs. West sniffed, "Living off ramen noodles and the cafeteria. I'm a mother, Haley. And all I want to do is take care of my girls—as long as you live with me, I'll make sure you have everything you need to live a happy, comfortable life."

"If that's the case, do you think you could slide me some more pancakes?" Haley pointed over to the oven eye with her fork, "I don't know what you did different this time, but these are great."

"Extra love." Mrs. West said matter-of-factly, "Or... extra butter. I'm not sure."

"Definitely the butter." Haley said, cheeks bulging.

141.content:
Haley had heard that going from high school to college was a rough transition. But as it turned out, having a two-year gap between one education to the next had made things even more rocky for her. In the span of two years, she'd forgotten most of the stuff that was covered in her Gen. Ed. courses in favor of things like how to calculate sales tax, how much her employee discount covered at her old job, and exactly how many times they could eat out on the dollar menu without going broke. Haley was spending most of her time at the USC Upstate campus relearning her introductory math skills, and realizing that the piddly papers she'd written in high school couldn't hold a candle to the ten-page monsters that her professors expected from her now.

Luckily, she wasn't entirely alone in her endeavors.

"Hey, we're still good for our study sesh after Bio, right?" A smaller shape bounded up towards her as she exited the Humanities building.

Courtney Caldwell was a familiar face, at least. They'd gone to school together back at Boiling Springs High (go Bulldogs!). She was in the grade below Haley, and they'd hung around the same group of friends. It was only by luck that Courtney had decided to take a year off herself, or she'd have been long done with the basic courses that Haley really needed her help with. She was shorter, with a fuller figure than Haley's. She had sandy brown hair in a boyish cut.

"Definitely." Haley shifted her backpack, "Wanna do Big Daddy's again?"

"Sure, I'll pay this time."

They'd been coming to Big Daddy's since they were old enough to drive. After-Church dinners and impromptu lunches after classes were all held at Inman's one and only diner; a mishmash of eighties, nineties, and early naughties' sci-fi and NASCAR memorabilia that belied the best chili cheeseburger that you could find in the tri-county area. Haley hadn't been in since she'd been home until Courtney suggested it a few weeks back, but after a heaping helping of bacon cheese fries she'd begun remembering why she'd loved this place...

"Whoa there. Hold up. Two patties? On one burger?" Courtney speared a stack of fries with her fork, "Madness."

"It's really good." Haley took a wide-open bite from her burger. Chili oozed from beneath the bun and onto the wax paper it'd been served on, "Hey, can I steal some fries?"

"Just order your own." Courtney made a face behind her glasses, "I think I can spare another five bucks if it keeps you from taking all the good ones. Again."

"You sure?"

"Yeah, totally." Courtney held a hand up, "Hey, can we get another order of bacon cheese fries here?"

It seemed like lately, all Haley had been doing was eating. The big breakfasts at home hadn't stopped, and she'd been coming into Big Daddy's every Monday Wednesday and Friday after classes. Mom was going cooking crazy now that Haley was back home, making all of her favorites for dinner almost every. it probably didn't help that she'd been grabbing lunch at the CLC every day either. That commuter money was good eatin', and it was one less meal she had to pay for...

By the time everything was said and done, Haley felt no better about the fit of her jeans than she did about her Math 102 course.

"Thanks for paying!" Haley waved goodbye in the parking lot, trying to suck in her swollen stomach, "I'll get you next time!"

She got in her car, tapped on her phone until Courtney had left, and then leaned back in her seat. Finally relaxing, her belly surged forward into a round turgid lump that curved against her t-shirt. God, she was full. The drive home was almost unbearable—five minutes down the road felt like twenty as she fought back the fullness of her own gut.

"I've gotta start cutting back." Haley puffed her way up the walkway, "Or I'm literally gonna explode."

Throwing her keys in the bowl by the door and tossing her half-done homework to the side, Haley collapsed on the living room couch. She laid one arm over her eyes to block out the sun as she rubbed her belly with her free hand. She felt like a garbage disposal—maybe she'd been eating too much of that greasy diner food after all. Her belly was just so round and soft. It hadn't always been like that, had it?

Her last clear thought before drifting off to sleep was that she needed to cut back...

"Haley~!" Came the voice of her mother, hours later, "Dinner's almost ready!"

And her first clear thought upon waking up was wondering what was gonna be for dinner.

At first, it was hard for Haley to go back to living under her mom's roof. She'd spent the past two years learning to fend for herself. Whether it was balancing her budget, saving up for new clothes, or even something as simple as what she was going to eat that night, Haley had learned how to do all of that for herself. When she was living with her roommates, she was the de facto adult. And now that she'd moved back in with her mom, she wasn't given much opportunity to flex those muscles anymore.

How do you go from earning a living wage and paying for your own things right back to asking Mom for money?

"Oh Haley, don't you worry about that." Mrs. West would always say, "You moved back in with me so I'd take care of you, and there's no shame in asking your Mom for a little spending money while you're going back to school."

At first it was hard. But Haley took to living by the purse straps of her mother quite well after a few weeks into the semester. She'd spent so long scrimping and saving, barely getting by on her own meager paycheck, she'd almost forgotten what it was like to not have to worry about money. It was like she was a teenager again! If she ever needed anything—money, food, you name it—all she had to do was ask.

"Mom, can I borrow a couple of bucks for some new jeans?"

"Mom, Courtney and I are gonna go grab a bite, and it's my turn to pay..."

"Mom, do you think you could grab me a couple Pop Tarts if you go by the kitchen?"

All in all, Haley took quite well to domesticated life. With no job and no other responsibilities besides keeping her grades up, the prodigal daughter fell into quite the sluggish lifestyle. Wake up, eat a big breakfast, go to classes, eat lunch, go to more classes, and swing by Big Daddy's with Courtney to study three times a week. Then she'd go home, take a nap, and eat dinner. It didn't take long before our formerly self-reliant protagonist to get more than a little lazy.

It was a Tuesday, almost halfway through her first semester back at college, and Haley West couldn't have been more of a sight. With her only class canceled for the day (something about a flu outbreak) Haley had been living like a queen. She'd rolled out of bed at ten, eaten her biggest breakfast yet, and bundled up on the couch. Parked in front of the TV, wrapped up in a cozy comforter and pajamas, with her brown hair all frizzed, Haley couldn't have looked more spoiled if she'd tried.

"Haley, sweetheart?" Mrs. West called from the kitchen, "Since you're home, do you want me to make you some lunch?"

"What?" called back, "No, I'm okay."

"Well you've got to eat, Hun." Her mother peeked her head around the archway, "Besides, you're never home in time for lunch. You've got to be hungry."

"I mean, not really..." Haley made a face, her cheeks catching against their newly acquired girth, "I mean, you just made me breakfast."

"I could order a pizza?" Mrs. West suggested with a zealous smile, "So you don't feel like you're working your poor old mother to death. (Even though you're really not.)"

"I mean..."

Haley thought long and hard about it—she hadn't had a pizza since she'd moved out. She could barely afford dollar menu, let alone pizza. At least pizza that was any good. And where would Mom order from? There was a Pizza Hut down the road, and Dominos was all the way in Boiling Springs. Pizza Hut had that stuffed crust, and their sauce was so much better than Dominos. Plus, they could order pasta, those breadsticks that she liked...

"Yeah, I could eat."

Almost an hour later, and you would have never known that Haley had eaten a stack of pancakes, half a dozen eggs, and half a container of bacon by herself. Mrs. West had ordered her daughter a whole pie, and it would barely last the hour. Bundled up in her lazy girl fortress of blankets and propped up with all kinds of comfy pillows, Haley snacked her whole day away!

A part of her felt guilty acting like this. The part of her that had learned the hard way that she couldn't just lay around all day. That there was work to be done and bills to pay. But as long as her mother kept insisting, Haley was going to oblige. And that felt bad shriveled up smaller and smaller was perhaps the only thing about Haley West that wasn't growing.

"Well you look comfy." Her mother said, waking her daughter up from an afternoon nap, "Aren't you going to meet with Courtney or something?"

"What? No, it's Tuesday. I'll see her tomorrow." Haley smacked her lips sleepily, her double chin catching slightly, "What time is it?"

"It's about half past four." Mrs. West brushed a clipped brown lock from being stuck on Haley's cheek, "Why don't you head up to your room, and I'll bring you your dinner when it's done? Sound good?"

"Mmmm..." Haley grunted sleepily, "Kay."

With as much trouble as one might expect from someone who'd eaten an entire pizza pie and its accompanying breadsticks, Haley rocked herself to a hunched position on the couch before rolling to her feet. Still cloaked in her comforter, Haley shuffled off down the hallway and into her room, where she collapsed face-first into her pillow.

"BURRRRRAP!" Haley belched as the contents of her stomach churned.

"What's wrong with having one little lazy day?" Haley thought to herself drearily as she drifted back to sleep, "I deserve it."

“We’ve got to start cutting back on the trips to Big Daddy’s.” Courtney said with a wry curl to one side as she bit into a forkful of cheese fries, “I think I’m starting to retain grease…”

Haley suddenly snapped to attention, cheese rolling from the inside of her mouth and onto her lips. She’d been hunched over her phone, scrolling through Facebook when Courtney had dropped the bomb. The shock was enough to rip her out of her headspace and back into the real world.

“What? But I like coming here!” Haley gasped, “These study sessions are the only thing that keeps me above water!”

“Well, yeah, we can still study, just in a less…” Courtney winced, “…dangerous environment.”

“Dangerous?” Haley made a face, “What kind of danger could we possibly get into at a Diner?”

As if summoned by the great gods of timing, their waitress for the evening emerged from the kitchen, turned corner, and approached the collegiate cuties with their dinner for the evening. Two burgers, double stacked, with so much chili that it spread against the sides of the wax paper. A refill of bacon cheese fries, and two baked potatoes. It wasn’t often that their waitress—Dina, or whatever her name was—smiled at them, but Haley couldn’t help but think that she looked much more pleasant than normal as she carried out the heaping helping of caloric content and hauled it all onto their plates.

“Order up!” their black-clad waitress said with a smile as she started doling out food, “Which one of you had the extra cheese, extra chili— “

“Ooh, me!” Haley raised her hand like a kid in a classroom as her burger was placed in front of her. A heavy slap against the table sounded at the impact.

“See, this is what I’m talking about. Haley, that’s like, your third chili cheeseburger this week.” Courtney cut her eyes at her gorging classmate, “All that can’t be good for you.”

“Hmm?” their waitress sounded as she doled out Courtney’s equally unhealthy helping, “Your food’s not good?”

“What?” Courtney blinked, “No, that’s— “

“Lemme talk to Petro about getting you some milkshakes.”

“No, Danielle, don’t— “

But it was too late! The goth girl skulked off, back around the corner to speak with the manager. Courtney rolled her eyes and let her head fall into her hands.

“Who’s Danielle?” Haley asked, her lips smacking loudly as she masticated her burger into mush

“I’m surprised with how often we’re in here, you still don’t know our waitress’s name. We went to high school together.” Courtney sighed, “Seriously Haley, I’m starting to get burnt out on Big Daddy’s.”

“Well, hey, that’s no big deal.” Haley slurped her sweet tea out of the Styrofoam cup, “We can always start hanging out at Waffle House or something. That’s close to campus.”

“We’re trying to escape greasy spoons, Haleykins.” Courtney said with a stab of her pile of fries, “Waffle House is probably worse than here. At least here we won’t get mugged.”

“Then… we could always eat on campus?” Haley searched her thoughts, “Oh! Or my Mom’s house—we’d save money at least.”

“The last time we studied at your mom’s house, I popped the button off my jeans.” Courtney grimaced, “I’m not going back there until I lose the twenty pounds I’ve put on since school started.”

In all honesty, Haley wasn’t listening. You never seem to realize how hooked you can get on a certain high throughout the day. And on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays—barring a couple Tuesdays where she was hankering a grilled cheese and couldn’t be bothered to go to class—Haley had certainly gotten used to having fatty, greasy food in her system. While Courtney blah, blah, blah’d her way through dinner about healthy choices, Haley was relishing in the flavors afforded to her by her staples. Chili. Cheese. And Burger.

“Sorry about your food, guys.” Danielle reemerged from around the corner carrying two more white cups, “These are on the house.”

Haley was practically drooling—she hadn’t had Big Daddy’s milkshakes since before she moved out!

“No thanks.” Courtney curled her nose, “I’m not feeling it tonight.”

“I’ll take hers.” Haley added greedily as she leaned across the table, her soft stomach cut against the edge, and palmed the side of Courtney’s shake. “Thank you!”

“Don’t mention it.” Their waitress smiled before walking off.

Far be it from Courtney to bring up anyone’s weight, but she was beginning to get worried about her friend. They’d known each other for years, and Haley had always been a little slip of a girl. But ever since they’d enrolled in college, she couldn’t think of a time when Haley wasn’t eating. On campus, here at Big Daddy’s, the random takeout they’d get when they hung out… and if her mother was anything to go by, Haley must live like a queen at home.

“Haley, are you okay?” Courtney asked after a long pause, “You’ve been eating a lot lately…”

“College is stressful—it’s called a coping mechanism.” Haley snorted as if it were the most obvious thing in the world, “It’s not a big deal.”

“Not yet it’s not.” Courtney furrowed her brow slightly, “But it’s gonna be a great big deal if you keep eating like this.”

“That was the lamest comeback I’ve ever heard.” Haley answered dismissively, “You’re worrying over nothing, okay? I’m totally in control.”

Haley slurped on her straw as creamy, sugary shake tickled her tongue.

“Total control.”

Coming home had its ups and downs for Haley. The ups were no rent, she didn’t have to have a job, and just about everything that her little heart could want was taken care of. The downsides were that she had to go to college, her classes were stressful, and she didn’t exactly have a lot of spending money. Her mom mostly took care of that kind of stuff, but still, she felt bad for asking. However, one of the unforeseen plus sides was the fact that she was given a great opportunity to reconnect with some old friends—at least, the ones that hadn’t gone on and done something with their lives yet.

Haley had known Mackenzie since they were in grade school, and while they were never “close”, they had been well enough acquainted that when Haley had met her at the beauty parlor it wasn’t weird that either should mention that they get together and catch up.

They were around the same age, but it was apparent that their lives had taken drastically different turns. Whereas Haley had moved out, had roommates, and eventually came back home to take a swing at college, Mackenzie hadn’t left their little home town for longer than a family vacation. She’d already settled down, had a baby… when were her friends old enough to start having babies?!

“God, I don’t think I could do it.” Mackenzie speared the fluffy egg portion of her All-Star Breakfast platter, “Go to college and actually finish, I mean.”

Haley had remembered Mackenzie as this toned, stringy Christian Athlete that had gone to the same Youth Group as her on Wednesday nights. Instead of sitting across from the fit sixteen-year-old athlete that she liked to remember, Haley was instead sitting across from a doughy mother of one who couldn’t seem to stop herself from wolfing down pancakes. She never would have guessed that she’d ever get fit, active Mackenzie Hollifield in a place like the Waffle House off of I-26, but wonders never ceased to amaze her. Then again, she’d never been able to picture Mackenzie as anything other than a size 0, and that had clearly changed as well.

Not that she wasn’t exactly interested in catching up with good ol’ Mack, it was just… well, past her bedtime!

Mom cooked for her at home too, but it had been so long since she’d been to the Awful Waffle! She’d ordered an All-Star Breakfast with extra bacon and toast, plus an extra pancake or two—she’d better not tell Courtney about eating so much after dinner; she’d probably wet blanket all over the fact that she got to catch up with an old friend!

The West house was a rather modest looking one. It was a three-bedroom, two bath, and was one of the many additions during the degentrification of the Boiling Springs area. Courtney had never actually driven there, and picking it out from the many other cookie-cutter homes proved to be somewhat challenging. She stood there, in the doorway, rang the bell, and pulled the hem of her shirt down over her bulging belly. It must have rolled up on the drive over…

“Hello Courtney, are you looking for Haley?” Mrs. West cooed as she stuck her head through the doorway, “She told me you might be coming by.”

Like her daughter, Mrs. West wasn’t the tallest woman. She had brown hair, though it was a bit more faded than her Haley’s, and held that same sense of benevolence about her. She was dressed very casually, in a loose Clemson sweatshirt and a pair of dark mom jeans. Her long brown hair was pulled up in a messy pony. Like Haley, she wore her weight well. She was a rather full-figured woman, but unlike Haley, she developed a full motherly set of breasts and wide birthing hips as opposed to her daughter’s spoiled gut.

“Hi Mrs. West!” the bespectacled chubster said with an awkward smile, “Yeah, I’ve got some homework for her from the past few days.”

The last time Courtney had walked through the threshold of the West family home, she’d left with a packed paunch and one less button on her pants. She’d wisely worn sweats to this little outing, and definitely not because they were the only things in her closet that fit her anymore.

There was a long pause as Haley’s tone corrected itself.

“C-Come in…” she said weakly from the other side.

“Hey Courtney…” Haley managed in her most pathetic voice, “What’s up?”

Haley’s bright blue eyes widened in what was surely an attempt to look even more pitiful. She coughed sadly.

Haley told Courtney about meeting up with Mackenzie and her recently recapitalized fears of not being good enough for college. And then a side note about how her mother had really enjoyed having her home, so it made the guilt a bit more bearable to see her so happy…

Haley and Dani had never been all that close—even back when they were friendly.

They had spent most of high school in the same social circles without ever really interacting. Mostly because Dani thought that Haley thought that she was better than her. And if that wasn’t the most high school thing that you’ve heard today, the only reason that they stopped hanging out a few years ago was because that Dani thought that Haley thought that she thought that she was a cunt, and was talking smack behind her back.

So sitting across from one another back at Big Daddy’s some time later, just the two of them, was… surreal.

“So—what’s up?”

Not seeing Dani squeezed into a waitress’ uniform, but rather plopped behind the other side of the booth after much shimmying and shaking, creaking wood and heavy breathing was almost as much of an adjustment for Haley as Dani’s new figure. The idea that she had been the chubby little goth girl who had waited on her and Courtney back when they were Freshmen in college was just… wow.

Dani’s sprawling acre of belly blubber poured onto the table’s surface, easing in and out like a gentle tide with her breathing. She was mostly gut, setting her aside from just about everyone else in Haley’s life. Where she was hippy, Courtney was top-heavy, and Mackenzie had been big all over, Dani was basically just a melted marshmallow of middle mass, white and chunky from every angle. Her chins formed a ring around her neck that quivered whenever she spoke—her voice still high and whiny from her days as a nagging little edge lord despite being somewhat slower and just a smidge more thick.

She had ordered off of the secret menu, and in abundance. Custom orders littered the table as she picked delicately from each and every tray like a queen holding court. Her chubby white fingers wrapped around this stick and that bun, stuffing each morsel into her mouth with the speed and dexterity that one would expect of a woman of her supreme size.

“Uh…” Haley gaffed, “Not… not much?”

Every time Dani leaned forward, she sounded a pathetic little grunt as she battled against her speedbag belly pinning her down in the booth. Her white little arm wings would quiver ever so slightly as she reached past her own hugeness for another bite of this or that. Honestly, Haley wasn’t quite sure how she’d even gotten in there… and she’d been present for the whole thing!

“So no boyfriend?” Dani’s round little face barely changed with the inflection, “Cool, cool, living the single life.”

“Are you… is this a date?”

“What?”

“Us two, together, eating out…” Haley immediately regretted her phrasing, “Is this, like a date or whatever?”

“God no, why the fuck would I want to date you?” Dani spat back, “This isn’t high school Haley, God, not everyone wants to jump your fucking bones, okay?”

Haley was, at the same time, relieved and disappointed. Like, one, okay yeah she didn’t really like girls. But on the other hand, it’s the New Twenties, and all girls are at least a little bisexual though. Why was Dani so opposed to the idea of hooking up? Rude. Hurtful. Maybe a little mean, considering the fact that Dani looked like someone left a marshmallow in the microwave too long trying to cook a s’more, but whatever.

“I’m here because… whatever, okay?” Dani sniffed as she cut into her first of three Greek-style chicken breasts, “Maybe I… maybe I fucking missed you guys.”

“Awwwww~”

“Shut up—do you want your fucking cheeseburger or not?”

Haley had never really thought much about why she and Dani had been friends in the first place. Truth be told, she wasn’t entirely sure that the pudgy goth could stand her. Seeing her as big as she as, it almost filled her with a sense of… it was hard to say. Pride? Maybe that she hadn’t managed to be the only person to blow up so big? Or maybe in the sense that she was still smaller than someone else? Maybe it was happiness—she and Dani had been friends for a while (apparently) and having Courtney constantly dip in and out of her life while her mom was starting to harp on her for getting a job… it was nice.

Big Daddy’s had a hard closing time of ten o clock in the evening, which meant that the two of them had a lot of eating to do if they wanted to get out of there in time for Petro and the girls to close up shop. Fortunately, neither of them were exactly familiar with the word restraint. Eating was second nature to the two southern sweethearts as they swelled over the table, happy to talk about old times. Haley caught Dani up on Courtney (and her stupid diet!) and did her best to avoid asking just what the fuck had happened to make Dani so goddamn fat.

They had been having a great time, truthfully—a rarity for the two of them, together. Given Dani’s general animosity towards Haley, it was almost surprising that the two of them could sit down together and have a cordial (if large) meal. Haley had been eased into a sense of security (though that may have been the food) and wasn’t at all suspecting just what was going to come out of Dani’s mouth next:

“So… are you down to smoke or something?”

Haley nodded her chubby little head yes. It had been a while since she’d partaken in the Devil’s Lettuce—it had never been her favorite party favor, always opting for the alcohol. But she’d never turned it down before, even if it did mean some more awkward face-timing with Dani. After all, it wasn’t like she had to wake up early in the morning for a job…

“Cool, cool… are you wearing that, or do you want to change?”

“…I’m sorry, what?”

“Nevermind, just…” Dani scrunched her face a little, “Whatever, help me out of this fucking booth.”

At the time, it had seemed like an odd question for Dani to ask.

“Are you wearing that, or do you want to change?”

Who asks that before you go smoke with someone? It’s just not a thing that you think to ask when you’re about to spark up a jay. Haley had just written it off as Dani being Dani. Once a gloomy goth girl, always a gloomy goth girl, despite tripling in size since she’d seen her last. Extra weight wasn’t the only thing that Dani had picked up though—she now sported two roommates that had been sitting in the living room when she and Dani walked into the house just off of Heron Circle.

The whole house was pretty dank. It was obvious how they’d intended to spend their night. Like Dani, Joni and Michelle had something of an alternative look to them. Where Dani was more dedicated to the Goth Girl Aesthetic ™, her roommates were more varied in style and in size. Joni had a more ambitiously neon coloration to her hair and clothing, was short and kind of big, where Michelle was just sort of… ordinary looking? (Was that the right way to say it?) Neither fat nor especially noteworthy, she was in an old holey band t-shirt and had been mid-rip of the bong when Dani managed to squeeze through the doorway.

Dani had led her to the couch, made a half-assed introduction (“this is Haley, we went to school together, she’s gonna smoke with us.”) and plopped down with a foundation-shaking kaboom next to her. The furniture had to be reinforced. Haley hadn’t put much thought into just how much she weighed until she’d started snapping furniture, but Dani was way bigger than her, and that couch was holding the two of them up…

Luckily for everyone involved, Haley wasn’t going to be doing much thinking tonight.

The little circle that had gathered wasn’t much more sophisticated than anything that Haley had experienced in high school—four girls passing around a bong, plenty of snacks, TV blaring. The only thing that was different was that no one’s parents were going to be home, and the alcohol was totally legal. And, just like back when she was in high school, Haley was a total lightweight—she hadn’t danced with the Devil’s Lettuce in years, and it showed in her stupid red-faced giggling. With the added appeal of alcohol, the bottom on Haley quickly fell out as she lowered herself into the couch for the night.

Unsurprisingly, Haley ate a lot.

She was already a self-admitted snack hog. Dani commanded the central flow of any and all things edible that were to be passed along the circle’s track, which put Haley in a precariously piggish position of being right next to the greediest girl in the room. Even without being stoned off her big round ass or drunk enough to fail a breathalyzer two yards away, would have definitely pigged out on the primo snack stash that Dani and her roommates brought out for their reunion smoke special.

Dani expertly worked her thigh-thick arms through the rotation of smoke, swig, snack while Haley struggled to keep up. She had the passion, but lacked the stamina. Engrossed in her vices, she barely contributed to the pitiful conversation of faux-deep philosophy that the other three managed. As time slowed down and Haley’s attentions narrowed in on whatever was placed in front of her, Haley could practically feel herself puffing up, and up, and up with every bite…

“You okay Haley?”

“M’feelingreattttt”

Haley pushed a heaping handful of Flaming Hot Cheetos into her mouth as she reclined against the back of the couch, her stomach surging outwards as it eeked out from underneath her shirt. Her fat cheeks full and flush, she turned to the source of the inquisition—Dani, sitting next to her in all of her pale, mountainous glory.

Her head was swimmy and stupid, filled with the nothingness that came with being high off her ass and drunk as a skunk at the same time. She was giggly and dumb, her chubby cheeks bouncing with laughter as she sunk slowly into Dani’s larger form. Almost like a moon succumbing to orbit.

She hadn’t been paying particularly good attention when somebody said it, so she wasn’t quite sure as to whether or not it was Joni or Michelle, but somebody said—
